148631834.review:
Stacking is a highly creative game that pulls it off OK.

I think as far as matryoshka doll based puzzle games, it's definitely the best in class. I think my biggest praise for this game is its originality - none of the puzzles felt reused from old games. However, some of the solutions were a bit too obscure to seem satisfying, and some hi-jinks just felt more like chores rather than fun extra projects to do (for instance, I think a lot of the hi-jinks where you have to do multiple of a thing would probably be more fun if you only had to do it once). 

To me, Stacking felt strongest at the beginning but had a bit of a weak end. The silent film cutscene dialogue is cute but does git a bit old, I think. Additionally, it's beginning to show its age at around 11ish years old now.

All that said, it felt nice to play something truly different. I'd get it when it's on sale for $5.

145693437.review:
Ladies and gentlemen, gather 'round, for I shall weave a tale of whimsy and wonder, of a game known as "Stacking," crafted by the masterful hands of Double Fine Productions. Imagine, if you will, a world where nesting dolls hold the key to solving puzzles and embarking on a grand adventure.

In this enchanting realm, you step into the tiny shoes of Charlie Blackmore, the smallest in a family of matryoshka dolls. A humble lad, no taller than your thumb, he possesses a unique talent – the ability to stack inside larger dolls, each with their distinct abilities and quirks. It's a world where size does matter, but not in the way you'd expect.

Now, picture a bustling, steampunk-inspired world, a wondrous place where each doll represents a character with a story to tell. From chimney sweeps to stern schoolteachers, each doll is a vibrant personality waiting to be discovered. As Charlie, you'll need to use your stacking prowess to navigate this intricately detailed world and uncover the secrets hidden within.

Ah, but what sets "Stacking" apart, you ask? Well, dear audience, it's the puzzle-solving that forms the heart of this narrative. You see, to progress through this charming world, you must stack into the right dolls to harness their unique abilities. Want to infiltrate a secret society? Choose the right doll, and you'll be granted access. Need to mimic a group of musicians to start a parade? Stack the musicians, and the streets will come alive with the sweet sound of success.

But here's the kicker – the puzzles are not merely mechanical conundrums; they're stories in themselves. The solution to each challenge unfolds like a miniature play, filled with humor and heart. As you stack and unstack, you become a puppeteer in this whimsical theater of life.

And what would a tale be without a sense of humor, you might wonder? Fear not, for "Stacking" is adorned with Double Fine's signature wit. The dialogues are laced with clever quips and charming exchanges, ensuring that laughter is never in short supply.

As our pint-sized hero, you'll embark on a quest to reunite your doll family and thwart the dastardly Baron, who's up to no good. Along the way, you'll delve into the lives and stories of the dolls you encounter, uncovering their dreams, aspirations, and even a touch of melancholy.

In conclusion, "Stacking" is more than just a game; it's an enchanting narrative experience, a whimsical journey through a world of nested wonders and endearing characters. It invites you to think outside the box, or in this case, inside the doll, and revel in the joy of storytelling through puzzles. So, my dear audience, if you seek a game that combines charm, humor, and ingenious puzzles into a delightful tapestry of adventure, look no further than "Stacking" by Double Fine Productions. It's a tale you won't soon forget.

[h1] 𝕌𝕟𝕚𝕢𝕦𝕖 𝕡𝕦𝕫𝕫𝕝𝕖 𝕘𝕒𝕞𝕖 𝕨𝕙𝕖𝕣𝕖 𝕪𝕠𝕦 𝕡𝕝𝕒𝕪 𝕒𝕤 𝕒... ℝ𝕦𝕤𝕤𝕚𝕒𝕟 𝕟𝕖𝕤𝕥𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕕𝕠𝕝𝕝? [/h1]

Yes, you've heard it right. In "Stacking", you're playing as Charlie, an investigative Sherlock type of dude looking to find his own sister, that was abducted into child labor efforts atop of a... blimp? You're helped by a bunch of other... ahem, Russian Stackdolls to find her.

The plot is so childish and nonsensical that you won't be paying much attention to it anyways; the real premise of the game is that you'd have to think outside the box to find innovative ideas to solve puzzles that the game refers to as Challenges. Each map has got a bunch of those challenges, and each challenge has a bunch of ways to solve!

To solve these puzzles you'd have to stack into unique nestdolls; however, you can only stack into a size that's bigger than the doll you're into right now... Ouff, that came out so wrong! Anyways, moving on... Each Stackdoll has got an ability, ranging from writing an obituary to shooting the other dolls' heads off, to... farting into a line of train passengers? 

This game gets a [b] 6/10 [/b] simply because I am with the opinion that with voice acting, a videogame becomes much more captivating than it is. Stacking lacks voices; it's got a great train-station western era soundtrack, but other than that the game's own greatness lies in how much thinking you'd have to do to figure out a puzzle. It's a great Puzzle Game but not so great a videogame overall, to be honest. Also, worthy of note that I encountered a game-breaking bug where I was stuck into a doll I could not unstack of or stack from, the problem is it was a huge doll and to proceed I had to be little old Charlie to get into a hole in a door... I lost like an hour of progress because of it, but it only happened once.

137692003.review:
As an avid gamer, I can say that Stacking is one of my absolute favourite games. It combines puzzle and adventure elements in a unique way and fascinated me from start to finish. Here are some reasons why I think Stacking is a great game:

1. innovative gameplay: the idea of stacking other dolls as a matryoshka doll, using their unique abilities, is a brilliant innovation in the puzzle genre. Each doll has its own strengths and weaknesses, and combining different abilities is the key to solving the puzzles.

2. charming atmosphere: The beautiful handmade settings and the lovingly designed dolls create a fantastic retro atmosphere that I absolutely love. The story is also very charming and humorous, which makes the game even more enjoyable.

3. varied puzzles: The puzzles in Stacking are very varied and provide a good challenge for players of all skill levels. There are a lot of secrets to discover and many hidden ways to solve the puzzles.

4. no pressure: One of the best things about Stacking is that there is no time pressure. You can take your time exploring the environment and trying out the different dolls without worrying that you will make mistakes.

5. entertaining fun: Stacking is a relatively short game, but it has a high replay value. There are many secrets and achievements to discover, which makes the game a pleasure to play over and over again.

Overall, I think Stacking is a fantastic game that combines unique retro atmosphere, excellent gameplay and challenging puzzles. I recommend it to any gamer who wants to experience something truly unique.

136716893.review:
I highly recommend Double Fine's game "Stacking" to anyone who loves adventure games and is looking for a unique and enjoyable gaming experience. This game is original and innovative. You play as a small Matrioska (Russian Doll) that can stack into bigger ones to possess their abilities. The whole game mechanics is based on this simple idea. Almost every doll you encounter becomes playable, and replaces items and actions in classical adventure games. The result is a more intuitive, direct and fast paced gameplay.

One of the best aspects of this game is the storytelling and humor, which is classic Tim Shafer. The writing is funny and full of quirkiness, making it an enjoyable experience from beginning to end. Additionally, the art style is simple but fantastic. The game feels like a great indie game, and it was obviously made with a lower budget compared to other Double Fine products.

The puzzles in "Stacking" are on the easy side, but each of them has multiple solutions -great idea!. It's easy to see the end of the story, but it might be hard to complete 100 percent without a walkthrough, making it a great game for gamers of all levels. The game can be completed in under 10 hours, a quick but enjoyable gaming experience.

However, there are a few cons to the game. The camera can sometimes work against you, especially is smaller rooms, which can be annoying. Additionally, in the last level of the main adventure, some objects that you can interact with were difficult to notice due to the dark colors used in that level. There is also one bug that I encountered where an achievement would not unlock even if I completed the game 100 percent. The lack of voice acting may be because of the low budget, but it's not a dealbreaker: they found a cool way to hide this aspect doing cut-scenes in the style of mute movies from the '30s (the result is super quirky since the characters do not have limbs and very limited facial expressions).

This game has no deep, rich story (it's nothing like Grim Fandango), it's a lighter take on the genre, characters are hollow and flat - but they are intended to be so. The game talks about serious themes child labor, capitalism, but in a humorous way. 

Overall, "Stacking" is an enjoyable and original game that is definitely worth playing. It's a small little pearl from Double Fine that showcases their talent, their love for adventure games and their will to reinvent the genre with new mechanics.

115745307.review:
Stacking is an exploration and interaction game. You roam around levels trying to figure out the various puzzles scattered throughout, but for the most part it isn't so much about solving a puzzle as it is finding secrets.

The game has a charming and fairly unique aesthetic. It takes place during the early 1900s with steam engines, barons and references to silent films, and the world is entirely populated by Russian nesting dolls. There are a lot of dolls to interact with and there are little cutscenes throughout the game to tell a story and let you know what is going on.

 The gameplay gimmick is that you are the smallest possible doll and can jump into larger dolls to control them, and each dolls comes with an ability to help you solve puzzles. Throughout each level are various challenges that can all be solved in a variety of ways. You can find just one solution and move on or stick around to find all possible ones. There are also various "hi-jinks" you can get into which usually involves using a doll in a humorous or unique way.

Overall the game is mostly carried by its charm and sense of exploration, as most puzzles are fairly easy to figure out once you have discovered the right doll. You will often find a puzzle and have no idea how to solve it, but then find a doll somewhere further away and immediately know what to do. Levels start of fairly contained but become large and sprawling. While it is possible to beat the game fairly quickly, in an hour or two, most people seem to take closer 6.

And this is where I admit I never actually finished the game. I had a good time in the first two levels, but by the third level the gimmick and gameplay started to feel pretty stale to me. The puzzles didn't really challenge me and while charming, I also grew tired of the setting. The sound is pretty bare bones and while the russian dolls feel like russian dolls, that means there is also not much in the way of animations. What I am trying to say is, yes the game has charm but not much else.

That said, because I got the game on sale and had a good time with it for several hours, and it is unlike most games I have played, I will still recommend it.

114952652.review:
A silly, compelling, fun, out-of-the-box casual adventure with original mechanics and great dialogue. Every area is a linear 'open word' (for a lack of better words), with no loading times and plenty of extras to keep you busy. Is it hard? No, but you're not playing for the difficulty, you're playing for the self-aware story and its characters. There is also a useful hint system, which is completely optional but may help with some of those hidden achievements.  

I'm not sure why I waited so long to play - for a game released in 2012, it really STACKS up in 2022. If you're a fan of games with charming characters, goofy hi-jinks, and unique visuals, you'll enjoy Doube Fine's "Stacking". Also included is a bonus DLC adventure, which I recommend doing after you've completed the main game. You'll definitely enjoy this if you're familiar with, and a fan of, Double Fine/LucasArts adventure games.

- I really liked the silent movie style cutscenes
- Finding the dolls and playing with their abilities (read: using their abilities to torment other dolls) was a lot of fun
- Decent story with plenty of laughs
- Lots of entertaining side-mission type things to do (hi-jinks, collect the unique dolls)
- Good level variety
- Great hint system that gives you two increasingly significant hints before giving you the answer. This prevents you from ever getting frustrated. I wish more games had hint systems like this.

Cons:
- Having a vignette on the cutscenes makes sense, but why is there a vignette on by default in the actual gameplay? In fact, why is it even an option? It just blocks part of the screen without really adding anything.

Verdict: 9/10

Stacking even though its not a very popular game is still one of my favourite games of all time. It contains a super engaging story and is a very nostalgic and unique game.  Although the origins of what the story is about is quite dark it is a really well made story. You play as Charlie who is trying to rescue his family from the leader the Baron. You go through different scenic maps like a cruise ship, train station, zepellin and more. The game has amazing graphics especially considering its 10 years old and are still great even to this day.

106550844.review:
This fun little adventure puzzle game is a great way to relax if you need something low stress. While a few of the late game puzzles have a bit of time pressure, most of the game can be played at your leisure, and the controls are simple and easy to pick up. 

The humor is a bit juvenile (lot of toilet humor, for example) but it's definitely cute and warm-hearted, and I got more than a few chuckles out of it. I did end up having to look up a few solutions, but only for optional completionist items, and there is an in-game hint system, as well as fairly robust environmental context clues. 

My only other complaint about the game is that it's a bit dark, literally - I had to bump up the brightness and lightning a fair amount to discern some of the visuals. 

I ended up completing the game 100% in about six sessions. Recommended for players of all ages and skill levels.

105739535.review:
My name is Hans and I like eating paint chips.

(100% On PS3)

Stacking is a puzzle game where you play as a Russian nesting doll in a semi-open world. Your character is an undersized doll that can "stack" (hence the name) into dolls that are one size bigger, which in turn can stack into dolls that are one size bigger, and so on. Dolls have unique abilities, some are just plain fun, but most serve a purpose, find the right doll for the job (puzzle) and progress in the story. There's usually more than one way to solve puzzles, so experimenting with different dolls to find out what they do and how that skill can be used is loads of fun.

One of my all time favorite games. Dialogue is hilarious, story is heartbreakingly fun, gameplay is great, and the atmosphere, oh God the atmosphere is so amazing. From the level design to the music, the entire world of Stacking is one I always want to go back. 

If you've never played this game and you enjoy laid back puzzling, a fun story, or just want to laugh at silly dialogue; What are you waiting for? Give this game some well deserved love!

Double Fine did not miss with Stacking; I absolutely adore this game. It is a cozy puzzle game at its core, with a storyline that is a scathing critique of 19th century industrialism (we love to see it). It is easy to achievement hunt, which is a pleasure for a completionist like me, has a great OST and aesthetic, and is so quirky, well-written, hilarious, charming. The list goes on. A casual playthrough (without hints) took me 5 hours, the remaining 6 were of me taking my time achievement-hunting and completing the Hobo King DLC.  The hint system is a wonderful component to jog my puzzle-solving abilities, the dozens of in-game achievements incentivize creativity and exploration. If played "correctly" every inch of every level is interacted with and I find that a hallmark of a good game to not waste *any* time or space.

Stacking is honestly a perfect game. Please do yourself a favor and experience this game and have a laugh while you're at it.

99610601.review:
[h1]Pros y contras[/h1]
[b][u]Lo bueno[/u]:[/b]
• Un título original y muy creativo que va a llamar la atención de jugadores casuales y experimentados por igual.
• Puzles divertidos y situaciones curiosas. Hay varias formas de resolver los puzles. Con que encuentres una de ellas es suficiente pero... ambos sabemos que no vas a descansar hasta que des con todas.
• Decenas de habilidades diferentes, que si bien individualmente no son la gran cosa, dan lugar a una gran cantidad de escenarios posibles.
• Hay presente un cierto componente de coleccionismo.
• Historia simple pero con un trasfondo y contexto interesante. Su final es muy épico siendo la cereza del pastel.
• Artísticamente me encantó. Recrea el estilo de las películas mudas.

[b][u]Lo malo[/u]:[/b]
• Me hubiese gustado ver con más frecuencia que a una misma habilidad se le den usos diferentes.
• Detalles menores como pueden ser:
- Consejos un poco molestos al comienzo del juego.
- Cámara un poco cerca del personaje (se puede arreglar ajustando el FOV desde las opciones gráficas).
- Algunos fallos en el audio en ciertos niveles.
- Entiendo que recrea las películas mudas, pero en muy contadas ocasiones el silencio se nota demasiado presente (por ejemplo en los créditos finales). Un sonido de estática o algo por el estilo contrarrestaría esta sensación de vació.
- A veces lo noté demasiado oscuro (visualmente hablando).

[h1]Desarrollo[/h1]
Si hay algo que me dejó claro este juego, es que la casa que lo desarrolló, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/developer/doublefine][i]Double Fine[/i][/url], encontró su hueco en el mercado de los videojuegos, y probablemente, un rinconcito en el corazón de muchos jugadores, gracias a sus obras rebosantes de creatividad. Cuando escucho el nombre de esta empresa, es lo primero que se me viene a la mente, creatividad en su estado más puro, y este título me recordó porqué.
Stacking es otra de las genialidades traídas de la mano de [i]Double Fine[/i]. Quizás no sea la más conocida, pero tiene una calidad y originalidad que la hacen digna de estar en lo alto junto a otras de sus obras.
Es una aventura de puzles en donde todos los personajes son [url=https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrioshka][i]mamushkas[/i][/url]. La principal peculiaridad o llamativo de estas muñecas rusas es el anidamiento, es decir, que unas muñecas contienen otras. Esta característica es el pilar base del juego y te va a servir para infinidad de cosas. Desde resolver puzles hasta camuflarse.
Todos los personajes tienen una habilidad que los distingue, que si bien individualmente no son la gran cosa, o algunas pueden parecer inútiles o demasiado específicas, la gracia está en descubrir dónde y cuando usarlas.
A lo largo de sus niveles, el juego nos irá presentando situaciones curiosas a las cuales llama "desafíos", que tendremos que resolver haciendo uso de nuestro ingenio, el anidamiento y las habilidades de los personajes que vayamos viendo por ahí. Lo genial de estos desafíos es que pueden ser resueltos de varias formas, y esto el juego lo tiene en cuenta marcándote las distintas soluciones que vayas descubriendo.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2603421485
Me pareció muy ingenioso este sistema, porque encontrar una solución no te debería costar demasiado (generalmente hay una que es relativamente sencilla para que no te pierdas y puedas avanzar con fluidez), pero encontrarlas todas (que es lo opcional y complicado, y que cada jugador decidirá si hacerlo o no) te va a aportar unas cuantas horas de diversión y de mucho pensar. Si bien es verdad que las recompensas por encontrar las soluciones son minúsculas, lo divertido está en el proceso de coleccionarlas todas.
Las habilidades de los personajes y el anidamiento es algo que el juego sabe aprovechar bien y de distintas formas. Como bien dije, individualmente las habilidades son algo simples, pero van a tener distintos efectos en el escenario o en otros personajes y merece la pena ir viéndolos. Además hay decenas de personajes distintos con sus propias habilidades, siendo algunos únicos (es decir que solo hay uno de ellos y no vas a poder encontrar copias por ahí, como ocurre con el resto). Estos personajes únicos quedan registrados y pueden ser vistos desde el menú, por lo que también habrá presente cierto componente de coleccionismo.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2604852117
No importa lo ridícula o inútil que parezca una habilidad, ninguna queda en el tintero y tarde o temprano el juego le va a dar su protagonismo, ya sea para resolver puzles o completando travesuras (que son tareas opcionales en forma de acertijos). La habilidades también se pueden combinar (aunque esto ya es casi al final del juego), por lo que todo esto la vuelve una experiencia variada y completa.
No es que lo haya echado en falta, pero repasando las habilidades conforme escribo esta reseña, se me vino a la mente lo interesante que hubiese sido ver un poco más de "flexibilidad" en el uso de las habilidades. Generalmente una habilidad la usás para una travesura, o lugar muy concreto y listo. No hubiese estado mal que algunas habilidades se usasen de formas distintas y en lugares distintos. Por ejemplo, los pedos de Meriwether Malolor se usan para completar una travesura, un puzle e incluso pueden ser combinados con la habilidad de otro personaje. Ver una habilidad que puede ser aplicada en situaciones distintas no es algo habitual en este juego, pero que sí me gusta bastante verlo, ya que me da la sensación de que se está aprovechando bien cierta mecánica, y de que sus creadores le están poniendo creatividad. En este juego no es tan relevante por la cantidad de habilidades distintas que hay, pero tampoco hubiese estado mal.
Su historia es muy simple pero me encantó. Encaja perfectamente con el estilo del juego y con la época y el marco histórico de donde se origina. Su eje principal son temas peliagudos como pueden ser la explotación infantil o la esclavitud, pero siempre las trata de una forma desenfadada, superficial y con mucho, mucho humor. Esto da pie a situaciones muy curiosas e interesantes, pero lo que más destaco es su final. No pudo terminar este juego de una forma más épica y divertida. Hasta en el último minuto supo sacarme una sonrisa y sorprenderme.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2604853835
Artísticamente es una delicia. Busca recrear el estilo de las antiguas películas mudas y lo vas a notar mucho en sus cinemáticas, música clásica y efectos de sonido (es verdad que esas películas no tenían ningún tipo de sonido o música, pero si lo hubiesen tenido, no creo que fuese algo muy distinto de lo que suena acá en Stacking). Gráficamente se ve muy bien. El brillo de los muñecos y el estilo que tienen todos me encantaron, hay algunos muy originales. Lo único malo es que me pareció un poco oscuro y sí hay veces que el silencio se nota muy presente (por ejemplo en los créditos finales). Incluso un sonido de estática hubiese venido bien para contrarrestarlo un poco. También en algún nivel puede que notes fallos en el audio del juego muy sutiles.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
[i]Double Fine[/i] es una empresa que arriesga en pos de traernos experiencias frescas, distintas. No atarse a una fórmula ganadora vista una y otra vez, porque a pesar del paso de los años, sigue ganando en ventas y amasando fortunas. Stacking es una de esas joyas que le muestra el dedo medio a esa fórmula ganadora, y que atrae la mirada de aquellos jugadores que busquen experiencias diferentes y ser sorprendidos a pesar de tener un amplio historial de títulos jugados.

89330739.review:
Stacking was a really fun game to play with its very original gameplay and unique design.

But first of all, it is not an adventure game as I had originally thought.
I don't know any other game it could be compared to.
I would qualify it to be a Russian dolls collecting game with humourous puzzles solving and in-game achievements hunting.


[b]Plot[/b]
The game plot is very simple. In a world of Russian dolls, in the early 20th century, we play as Charlie Blackwood, the smallest Russian doll in the game, and have to free every other members of our Hobo family from the clutch of an evil Baron.

The game also offers a free DLC with a new story where Charlie will have to free 3 blacksmiths in order to forge the crown of the lost Hobo king.


[b]World[/b]
The game world is inhabited by Russian dolls of all sizes and looks, and each different looking doll has a very specific ability that can be used on other dolls or objects.
 
There is one central location, the train station, from where we can travel back and forth to 3 other locations. 
There are also 2 other small locations at the end of the game, but those are plot related only and are visited only once.


[b]Animations[/b]
The whole animation process of all the wooden dolls, stacked or not, is extremely well done. The devs really showed great expertise in giving life to all those rigid hollow dolls.

The game has no voice-over, but as we progress in the game, the story is told to the player through silent movies cutscenes. The animation is so well done that we really felt a doll was actually talking despite its unmoving face.


[b]Soundtrack and sound effects[/b]
A wonderful soundtrack of classical music accompanies us as we play and fits extremely well the gameplay. And even if dolls do not have a voice, all kind of sound effects, onomatopea, crowd noises... really make this dolls world into a vibrant and lively place.


[b]Gameplay[/b]
As the smallest doll, Charlie is able to stack into any one size bigger doll in the game (as long as they are not facing him) and so on, to then be able to use their unique ability.
In order for the plot to progress, in each location we visit, we are given several mandatory challenges to complete. Those challenges, or puzzles, require to figure out how to use the abilities of the dolls at our disposal to complete all kind of more or less zany tasks (such as fixing a clock, close down an Egyptian exhibit or disabling a sickly guard). 
Stacking into all those dolls and testing abilities was really fun. The extent of the available abilities was really funny at times as some of them really tend to be quite silly.
The game fully encourages the player to try and test any abilities on everyone and anything.
And if we are stuck, each challenge has an in-game hint system that will guide us on what to do next.


[b]Controls[/b]
- WASD to move.
- Left click to stack into a doll.
- Right click to unstack.
- Q to talk to a doll.
- E to perform the current stacked doll ability.
- Space to show the way to the next plot related task.


[b]Optional content[/b]
The game could be completed in a few hours, but where it really shines is with its optional content that may add a good 10 hours of fun gameplay:
- Each location has a number of unique dolls to find and stack into, in order to collect them all.
- There are also Hi-Jinks, in-game achievements, where we have to complete a certain number of actions with (a) certain(s) doll(s).
- Each challenge also has between 3 and 6 possible solutions. Even if finding only one is enough to progress with the story, finding all of them is quite fun and unlocks some unique dolls we could not have stack into otherwise.


In all, Stacking was an extremely fun game that I recommend to anyone. But you will have to play it yourself to really understand how fun it is

82794495.review:
(This game was a gift from a friend)

Stacking, like all Double Fine games, is a bizarre story full of irreverent humor and innovative game mechanics. You play as a tiny Russian nesting doll and solve puzzles by stacking (haha!) into larger dolls and using their unique abilities: from serving soup to giving wedgies.

The story itself is told through silent movie-type cutscenes, where you see the action happen on a stage and the dialogue comes after on a slide. It's... strange, but endearing, although the dialogue is intentionally eye-roll worthy at times.

I have only two major complaints about the game:

1. The movement isn't that great. It [i]sort of[/i] makes sense for it to be stiff since you don't actually have any feet, but it's incredibly annoying that you can't turn without coming to a dead stop first. You can sometimes get around this by maneuvering the camera instead of turning with the left stick (I use controller) but it doesn't always work.

2. The distance blur is awful. It makes it difficult to see what you're heading towards and which dolls are far away from you, and since the camera is so close to your butt anyway, it means you don't have a very large field of view.

Overall though, the game is quirky and pretty fun if you enjoy puzzles, and full price isn't even a bad deal.

76068000.review:
Stacking is a weird game. 

It has a unique game mechanic that allows players to use the abilities of every NPC and solve story related puzzles that all have multiple solutions with multiple characters and approaches. It's kinda like a story based systemic sim. It allows for a great deal of experimentation and goofing around. 

To facilitate this gameplay, the style and setting is excellent. The writing is also a highlight and brings the world of dolls to life, creating a unique experience.That being said, the game is more about goofing around than anything else. While finding alternative solutions to puzzles is fun at first, there is no larger story or any kind of progression to the game. 

This is unfortunate, because a weird narrative is only weird for a while, once we understands the logic behind it, it looses some of its nuance. This is when some kind of new game mechanic or character progression should have been implemented. The way it is now, the game just gives you all its tools on the first level. This is my only gripe, and the only reason I was not interested in finishing the final levels.

75025788.review:
Stacking - Review

Stacking is one of the lesser Double Fine games. Which means it still has some excellent qualities. This time though there are also some glaring issues.

The visuals and art style are as so often imaginative, detailed and just lovely. One of Double Fines greatest strength, imagining and realizing a interesting and visually engaging world is here clearly in display.

However, gameplay has always been one of their issues, either only being halfway realized or somewhat unbaked.
This is here even worse. The actual gameplay is at the start interesting due to the novelty of the ideas and world. But soon the player will realize that they translated Pint and Click Adventures greatest weakness into this game. The gameplay comes down to grabbing the next somewhat logical character and then rubbing them against the Challenge or Mission.

Even worse, beyond the visuals the games other elements like the sound and how the game feels to play, are so muted that even the very whimsical designs could not safe me from being bored. The game also offers you to scour the levels for collectibles like more unique dolls or little tasks like push 10 people with a certain character. You could do that either by first play trough of a level or by coming back later after the story completion.

But i will be brutally frank here: i was so bored of the tedious back and forth that by the third level i just wanted to finish the story and pushed trough the game to at least see the great artstyle.

The story sadly does not do anything to endear itself. Its story feels whimsically forced with some really awkward passages in the dialogue that feels like it is written by a first timer. The way it is presented, in the Silent Movie style (scene, then some text displaying the dialogue, then next scene and again dialogue and so on), only adds to the tedium, stretching every scene unnecessarily in the length. Even worse is that towards the end you nearly have more of these stretched out scenes than there is gameplay, exacerbating the issue of tedium and boredom even more.

I appreciate the craftsmanship and the love to detail that clearly shows Double Fines expertise here. However the rest is sadly far under what i once expected of the studio. I personally would therefore not recommend this game. However the prize is rather fair so if this sounds like something you might like it definitively has some artistic quality to offer.

74049212.review:
[b]If you’re looking for something truly different and unique, play this game[/b]

Stacking is a breath of fresh air. An adventure puzzler (which means you go on an adventure and solve puzzles along the way) unlike any other game on the market, this game is oozing with charm as many other Double Fine games. 

Wrapped in a fantastical diorama setting with silent movie-style cutscenes, Stacking actually tells a rather depressing tale of child labor. Solving the primary challenges to progress the plot is only part of the gameplay, you'll actually spent far more time exploring the environments and experimenting with different doll abilities. 

Each world has a cast of unique dolls to find and collect, some standalone and some that come in matching sets. In addition, various of them have "hi-jinks" goals that you can find by experimenting with their abilities. Challenges ( aka puzzles) all have multiple solutions too, so you can redo them until you find all the possibilities. This version also includes the DLC published on other platforms.

From a strictly technical perspective, you could call a lot of these extras filler, because they do go far in padding out the play time. But does it matter if something could technically be considered filler when it's so fun? 

From the very begining, Stacking very well win you with its charming presentation. If you are reading this, it's time to stop now and play the game.

Thanks [b]GGPlayers[/b] site for this awesome gift! <3

73993943.review:
You play as Charlie, the smallest of the Russian stacking dolls, as he attempts to rescue his older siblings from child slavery subjected by the Baron. Charlie's adventures take him to a train station, cruise liner, and zeppelin as he attempts to find all his siblings. Each area offers quite a lot of content to explore and a number of puzzles to solve in order to rescue Charlie's enslaved siblings.

Each area contains a number of different Russian dolls, and each type of doll has a specific ability. Some of the special abilities are used to solve puzzles, but many are included merely for added variety and fun. There are about 30 different types of dolls in each area, most of which are one-of-a-kind. Charlie can hop into progressively larger Russian dolls in order to use the abilities of the various dolls. This core mechanic offers not only a unique gaming experience, but also merges seamlessly with the puzzles.

The puzzles in each area arise as Charlie learns where his siblings are being held and what needs to happen in order to set them free. For example, one sibling is forced to clean the smoke stacks on a luxury cruise ship and Charlie knows his sister will be set free if he can end the cruise. He then sets out to upset the VIPs on the ship and get them to complain to the ship's captain. Without this merging of story and puzzles, I doubt the game would feel nearly as enjoyable, but by merging these two aspects together, I actually felt like my actions were having a worthwhile impact on Charlie's quest.

The story and writing are okay. The story seems to rank second with the primary focus clearly placed on the puzzles. A lot of the roaming doll dialogue is repeated, but you don't spend a lot of time talking to the other dolls so I don't consider that to be a problem. There is an appropriate amount of humor mixed in, to include well-placed references to both popular and esoteric historical and pop-culture material. I recognized Lord of the Rings, Shakespeare, Poo-pourri, and the Spice Girls to name a few.

Art direction in this game is fantastic. The environment and the dolls are highly detailed and animated, which really enhances the doll-stacking aspect of Stacking. The scenery in each level uses life-size items like dice, playing cards, salt and pepper shakers, popsicle sticks, thimbles, and bananas, which strongly give the feeling that the dolls you encounter are actually doll-sized. Every doll is painted with exquisite detail and has a distinct personality. This detail combined with the small animations added to each doll and their special abilities makes them feel real rather than feeling like two pieces of wood wobbling through the world. I found the concept of possessing different dolls in order to perform specific actions very unique and enjoyable, and this is only improved by the design and animations. I also really enjoyed the silent film style to the cutscene videos which really helped to set the atmosphere for game set in the 1930s era. Everything merges together for a truly immersive experience.

The puzzles themselves were not very challenging and many simply required you to roam around the map and find a specific character that could cause something to happen. This type of solution could occasionally be tedious if you hadn't yet seen the appropriate doll, but most of the time I felt like I already knew what I needed and then set out to find that doll that I suspected would solve the puzzle. Each puzzle also has multiple solutions, so you could quickly advance through the game if you settle for the first solution. I preferred to find as many solutions as possible, but ultimately gave up on many puzzles when I simply could not discover the final one or two solutions.

I played using both keyboard/mouse and gamepad controls. I personally preferred the gamepad controls, especially since I felt that provided better camera management. The controls are incredibly simple though so it really doesn't matter which setup you use.

This is a charming adventure game with a ton of personality but not a lot of depth. If you stop to examine what you're actually doing as you play the game, stacking dolls is really the only mechanic here. Fortunately the game is short enough and the environments varied enough that I never grew tired of the game. Some of the puzzle solutions can require a bit of a stretch in imagination, but that will only slow you down if you want to find every possible puzzle solution. For those struggling with finding even one solution, an in-game hint system will give you anywhere from a nudge in the right direction to outright step-by-step instructions if that is what you need. This isn't the greatest puzzle adventure game available, but it is certainly a unique and enjoyable game.

If you enjoy Stacking don’t forget to also play the free additional level, The Lost Hobo King. This level continues sometime after the main story ends, adding a new set of dolls and featuring slightly more difficult puzzles.

I love this game.

You play as Charlie, a Dickensan hero and the littlest Russian Doll. Charlie has to rescue his family  and also rescue other kidnapped children who have been kidnapped by the evil robber Baron industrialist. A villain who all but twirls his mustache.

As the littlest doll, he's able to jump into other dolls around who are one size bigger than him at a time and use their special ability's to get around obstacles in his path. It's fun to just mess around with the abilities and I found how the dolls move around and operate very charming.

There are a variety of ways to solve almost all problems in the game (with bonuses for finding all solutions)
It's not the most challenging of games, although a few alternate puzzle solutions might be tricky.
 
I enjoyed the Machine Era setting with the trains, steam ships and Zeppelins. It also shows the dark side of the era with child labour in dangerous conditions of mines and factories, crushing poverty and exploitation of the workers. But with charming Russian Dolls. It keeps a cute aesthetic throughout this though so it is suitable for all ages. I think the art style is gorgeous. I prefer stylised animation to super high-definition graphics. And the game has lots of silly, fun moments.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#454 out of 612)... it's time for Stacking.

You know what would make for a great game title? Just a single, generic verb.

It's not even a pun.

Anyway, I'd probably qualify Stacking as developer Double Fine's weakest game to date. It's a simple adventure game with a charming premise and aesthetic, simple puzzles and excellent music... but, I dunno, it just never quite clicked for me. I didn't find it compelling or memorable and every time I see it in my library, thanks to that inane title, I find myself thinking, "what the heck even is that?" And then I look at the story page and scratch my head for a few minutes before remembering: "Oh yeah," I'll say to myself. "It was pretty okay."

And by the next day I'll have forgotten about it again.

52215259.review:
Double Fine takes a setting not normally associated with cheery adventures, the Great Depression, and turns it on its head by focusing on the story of little Charlie Blackmore, the tiniest boy ever. In a world of Matryoshka dolls, he can uniquely hide inside of other people and use their status or abilities to solve puzzles as he looks for his lost family members.

It's a very simple premise, possessing others to use their powers, but there's such a charm to it. Not unlike Psychonauts and Brutal Legend, Stacking has a very quirky sense of humour that isn't afraid to make fun of itself. It's beautifully stylistic, with all the scenes playing out like silent movies. You even have set pieces slide into place as the scene builds itself.

There's a central hub and three other locations unlock as you progress, plus there's a expansion chapter that takes place afterwards in a town full of hobos! Every location has unique dolls to find, sidequests to solve, and all the story challenges have multiple solutions. If you like cute games then this is definitely worth taking a look at.

I really wanted to like this game. I even re-installed it hoping to give it another try. But the dour graphics and the overly simplistic gameplay just didn't do it for me. I'm a big fan of games that are quirky/charming, and I was hoping Stacking would fit that bill. While it does attempt do that, I simply found the game too childish and repetitive. The gameplay basically consists of hunting down the right doll, stacking into it, and then pressing A at the right location. This basic gameplay loop got old almost immediately and I found myself wondering if this was all there was to the game. The fact that it lacks voice-overs takes away from its sense of charm. I probably might've enjoyed this more if I had played it at another time but I came into this on the back of Valiant Hearts, and thus, this was quite a down turn for me.

Either way, I'd still recommend you try it out for yourself but it just didn't do it for me. I tried to like it. It's not a bad game. It's just really really boring and I found myself just playing to get it over with.

Final verdict: 5/10.

The game isn't bad, but neither is it very good. I really wanted to enjoy this game so bad, but it falls short. It had a lot of potential, but it's not as creative as it could had been. All of the puzzles are pretty obvious and a little too straight forward. The game never picks up on difficulty either, it all feels the same just with a different story and setting, which is quite repetitive. The different abilities are crafty, but they could had a much larger use, and many are never even needed to get through the game. It seems like you are only ever looking for one doll at a time. Instead they could of had it where you needed to stack strategically, in other words you would need a certain combination of dolls. Also the game as whole is very very short. The game can be completed in only a small handful of hours. The look and feel of the game is great! It just begs to be something so much bigger and more sophisticated, but instead it is simplified and just kind of boring overall. Even the story hardly does any justice. I found the story pretty dull, and not very exciting. The cut scenes were annoying if anything.
One thing that does make this game kind of fun is finding all the unique dolls and trying to figure out all the little achievements called Hi-Jacks. Sadly, now that I completed the game, I don't think I will getting 100%, at least anytime soon. For casual players this game might be worth the couple of hours.

44631440.review:
Stacking es una de esas atípica propuesta que de vez en cuando los jugadores nos encontramos como una sorpresa y que rebosan originalidad por los cuatro costados. Desarrollado por Double Fine Productions, con el siempre genial Tim Schafer a la cabeza, esta propuesta del género puzles nos lleva hasta la revolución industrial en una suerte de universo habitado por matrioskas —muñecas rusas— en la que deberemos ayudar al joven Charlie Blackmore a encontrar a su familia secuestrada.

Con un tono siempre desenfadado y simpaticón, envuelto en el sentido del humor tan característico de Schafer, se nos presenta una historia de época con injusticias de clase social y precariedad laboral. Se aprovecha este filón para adaptar el humor al concepto jugable y así ofrecernos situaciones como manejar a una [i]femme fatale[/i] para distraer a un guardia o atraer unas ratas a la cocina de un restaurante de alta clase vestidos de flautista de Hamelin para desalojar en lugar. Como descubriremos al poco de jugar, una de las gracias del juego es hacer gamberradas con las habilidades de cada personaje e ir descubriendo las formas alternativas que nos presenta el juego de resolver los puzles a partir de ello.

En nuestra aventura deberemos pasar por toda una serie de diferentes escenarios, todos ellos representativos de los avances en transporte de la revolución industrial, que harán las veces de niveles de estructura abierta donde resolver los puzles que se pongan en nuestro camino. Cada nivel sigue la misma estructura de desarrollo que se resume tal que así: introducción cinemática con el conflicto del nivel, se nos pedirá que busquemos a unas matrioskas concretas, investigaremos el escenario en busca de puzles que resolver, tras resolver cada puzle se liberará a una de esas matrioskas, cuando encontremos todas podremos acceder al final de nivel. Por el camino, y para hacer más variada la aventura, se nos plantean siempre tres objetivos secundarios: encontrar un número de matrioskas únicas con habilidades especiales, juntar una pila de muñecas de la misma temática y realizar una serie de travesuras que iremos descubriendo conforme interactuemos con los personajes y escenario.

La propuesta jugable no es especialmente complicada, de hecho no pretende serlo, y nos ofrecerá la posibilidad de acceder en cada puzle a un total de 3 pistas, a cada cual más evidente. De igual manera el diseño de los escenarios dará pistas a los jugadores más observadores y al conversar con las muñecas recibiremos sutiles pistas para los puzles desperdigados por el escenario.  En total terminar el juego nos llevará alrededor de 5 horas y 10 si queremos sacar el 100% del juego. Si añadimos el DLC que se incluye con el juego podemos sumarle otra hora más de diversión.

El apartado de arte, como ya se ha mencionado, evoca la época de la revolución industrial bajo el prisma de un universo hecho de muñecas rusas y reconstruido con objetos cotidianos como cajas de cartón de huevos o enseres de cocina. Todo ello en forma de homenaje a los inicios del cine simulando una película muda, con el sonido del cinematógrafo de fondo, el ligero ruido en la imagen y las esquinas oscurecidas de la proyección. En el apartado sonoro la banda sonora resalta por las melodías de época a piano del cine mudo y los efectos sonoros de las muñecas, muy divertidos y cómicos.

En conclusión Stacking es una propuesta muy recomendable dentro del género de los puzles, bastante asequible y que no es especialmente complicado, y que encuentra su miga jugable al invitarnos a tratar de encontrar todas las formas alternativas de resolver los puzles que se nos presentan en el trayecto. Una propuesta ligera y que te haga reír de vez en cuando mientras le das vueltas a la cabeza.

44398687.review:
I'm going to recommend this, but with a few warnings. 

Stacking feels like it accomplished what it set out to do. It's a cute puzzle game with a pretty neat concept. Basically, you enter an area in which a problem needs to be solved. Stacking into other dolls gives you a new ability to help you solve that problem. That's pretty much the game. Your ONLY abilities are "Talk" and stacking into other dolls to get new abilities. Late in the game it opens up a bit and forces you to start combining abilities, but only at the tail end. 

The few problems I had? The controls are a bit sluggish. Stacking works fine, but moving around (you sort of just bounce since you're a nesting doll) is a bit of a chore. The game's style is also unique, but may put some people off. It's done as a silent movie, with all text coming up as cards between scenes. Beyond that there really isn't much in the way of audio besides a few sound effects, ambient noise and piano to accompany the game play. 

There's also a fair bit of backtracking and the field of view when you're the smallest doll (Charlie) is sometimes a bit of a pain. 

Other than those gripes it's not bad, just know what you're getting in to.

Well, I never thought I would sink 10 hours into a game about Russian stacking dolls, but here I am. 

Overall I really like how the game was done, the mechanics are clever and entertaining for people of many senses of humour. The art and colours were fun and I never found a time where I was getting bored of the environment. 

I'm not the kind of person who plays puzzle games to brag about getting through all of them on wit alone, I sometimes get stuck on them and need a hint and luckily this game provides in a way that I love. They give you two hints and a more direct explanation if you can't figure out what you need to do, making you wait for a while between hints so it gives you time to think. In addition, no puzzle in this game has a set solution. You're given multiple options to overcome an obstacle, which makes the game so much more fun. Being able to think outside the box (and even be encouraged to do so!) is something I appreciate in a puzzle adventure game.

I'm a big fan of the things that Double Fine puts out and this game doesn't disappoint. If playing a laid back and unique puzzle game about taking down child slavory via possessing larger Russian dolls sounds intriguing, this might be for you.

42355653.review:
If you like quirky games, some weird collectibles, and puzzles, you'll enjoy Stacking.

It's not perfect, and the camera control combined with the movement controls leave something to be desired, but I really am enjoying this game (It's telling me I just hit 50%). It's also quite slow to start, and you don't really get to start playing until 15-20 minutes in. This is mostly becaues the cutscenes are styled like a silent movie; this is cute at first but becomes unbearably slow at times when you just want to get back to puzzle solving, as the scenes are unskippable.

The game is based around being a stacking doll, nesting into other dolls to change your size and ability. Each level features several problems that can be solved by using certain dolls. Nothing feels to repetititve, as each problem features multiple solutions, from the obvious to the hidden and clever. One thing I really appreciate is the structure of the hint system. If you can't figure out a way to solve a problem, or you've only found some of the solutions, you can read a hint with no deductions, demerits, or punishmnet whatsoever. Each solution features 3 hints: One to give a vague concept that might spark an idea of the doll to use, one to provide a bit more clarity, and the last one all but spells it out for you. The hints are on a timer, so you have to wait about 10 seconds to see the next hint, but I feel that this encourages me to think about what the hint says and solve it myself before just clicking through to see the solution.

Each level also features Hi-Jinx, fun little 'side-quests' to do with the less important dolls. Maybe you need to stun 10 other dolls with the photographer's flash, or fart on 5 passersby. These aren't required, but they're fun to find and grant the doll used a special gold accessory.

Overall, there are some small flaws, but I think that especially for the price, this is a solid puzzle game with interesting concepts that can be a quick breeze-through in 3-4 hours or can be played for longer, exploring every area, every doll, and every Hi-Jink.

39032425.review:
Finished [b]Stacking[/b] on the 04.Jan.2018


[b]Who are the game developers?[/b]
Double Fine ([url=http://www.doublefine.com/]Double Fine[/url])


[b]What's the game about?[/b]
Charlie's nightmare! oh, and puzzles!


[b]General feeling after finishing?[/b]
The Blackmore's are saved, hoorah! I've not seen another game out there quite like this one, from the graphics to the gameplay. It is a charming adventure full of humour and silent-movie-like cutscenes, and overall fun. If you're like me and enjoy a good story tied to great visuals, you'll probably get hooked by the many videos you may find of gameplay and trailers, and then buy it.


[b]Story?[/b]
Charlie Blackmore thinks he's a doll. He sets out to try and rob the personality of other "dolls" by incorporating them. In the midst of this he thinks his doll family has gone missing and sets out to "find them and destroy them" (Matrix fan much?). He finds his family (let's call it that!) being enslaved by a corporate industrialist whom he sets out to also destroy. His family is now no longer poor, so Charlie abandons them to go play with trains.


[b]Gameplay?[/b]
Very interesting concept and realization. As a matryoshka doll you're able to stack inside other dolls (thus the name, duh) and perform different actions with these to solve a whole lot of (sometimes very convoluted, to the point that there is an in-game hints system) puzzles. At a later part in the game, the dolls have to combine their powers (actions) to solve various even more difficult puzzles (e.g. the fireman shoots water for the fan boy to cause a sniffle attack on a guard keeping one of Charlie's - that's the main character - family members). Apart from this stacking element, there's also "quests" like finding a particular set of dolls that you have to stack or finding 26 different dolls in a level, or provoke effects on other dolls to get rewarded with a bip-star sound, whicih make for a nice extension of the adventure.


[b]Graphics?[/b]
I especially like the vignette style of visuals, and the movement of the dolls, the way they stack and unstack and are used in different context makes for an appealing adventure.


[b]Sound & Music?[/b]
Nice sound effects, coupled with lively music set to the era.


[b]Replayability?[/b]
A whole lot of it, especially if you're a completionist and want to get 100% done and not just run through the game in 50 minutes or so.


[b]Time played?[/b]
Around 12 hours.

39029767.review: Intersting concept with some clever puzzles, a good quick puzzle game.

39013631.review:
Stacking is a game I have enjoyed so much, and for so many reasons! I personally cannot think of too many bad things with this game, but there are many good things. The game has charm, created by its style. Stacking also has a pretty good message in it about child labour, and the gameplay is amazing!

The game has a strong charm with the style chosen to be 'stacking dolls'. The stacking dolls provide a very nice painted look to them, which goes well with the overall style of the game. This is very unique when it comes to video games, and I am yet to come across another video game that implements nesting dolls into their character design. The music also goes well with this style. Many cutscenes in the game are a sepia tone, with old film effects such as film burn, to create a feeling of time. This feeling of time is very important to the story of the piece.

The story of the piece is mainly about child labour and poverty. The protagonist in the video game is a child, who is the smallest doll in his set/family. This child's siblings get sent away through child labour trafficking on a boat. The young kid has to overcome many obstacles and utilise his size to overcome the illegal forced child labour scheme. In the process he befriends a homeless man, and this homeless man ends up being basically the only person who stays with you throughout the game. The game describes the effect being poor has had on the protagonist, and his family, as well as displaying homeless and poor people to have humanity and dignity, which can be rare in many forms of media, let alone video games. Although the representation of homeless and poor people wasn't perfect or complete, it was quite a positive one, which is important. And it is especially important to show how children are affected by poverty, as that is rarely discussed.

The gameplay is really so much fun! Utilising the nesting dolls, the protagonist is able to disguise himself with many different types of dolls, creating an aspect of stealth, or to use doll's abilities to solve puzzles, creating aspects of puzzles.  This can be surprisingly challenging, and very rewarding when completed. With every puzzle, there are multiple ways to solve it, and the game will always let you go back to previous areas to complete and collect, making the game great for perfectionists!

There may be some bad aspects to the game that I have forgotten about, or didn't notice, but overall, Stacking is quite a gem of a game! Stacking uses a very old and well-known item, and completely uses it in a new and different way, making for a familiar, but new experience.

Stacking is a great little adventure game.

36242971.review:
Stacking is a game based on the Russian Matryoshka Dolls. It is another tiny novel feather-in-the-cap for Tom Schafer, the creator of Psychonauts. The game involves you, Charlie Blackmore, going on an adventure to rescue your family from the clutches of the evil Baron. 

Gameplay-wise, you move around stacking into dolls that are one size larger than you and then using them to stack into other dolls. Each type of doll has an unique ability that only it has. 

Conclusion, do try this game. While it is absurdly simple and short, the novelty is pretty cool. It can be greatly improved with a few suggestions. Only 15% of all accounts have ever completed the Final Challenge.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Interesting and Innovative Game Mechanic
Using the Matryoshka Dolls is pretty fun.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Way Too Short
It takes only 4 hours to complete the main and the DLC.

2. Same Puzzle, Same Outcome
While there are multiple ways to solve the puzzle, it makes the game feel extremely short and boring if you play the same puzzle over and over again. If you had so many innovative solutions, why not make more puzzles instead of focusing them all on 1 puzzle?

3. Boring Levi Collection
That shiny Hobo collection is not any incentive to replay the game. Make the collection come alive. No one wants to look at a jigsaw puzzle.

4. Story is Bland
Evil Baron and the need to save a family? That's like bad writing. If the Camel Toe reference wasn't bad enough, I would just fire Tim Scafer's writer. If he wrote it himself, stop writing and let someone better take over.

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Team Ups
This game could be solved with puzzles similar to Lost Vikings. Remember Olaf's shield? You could stack a team of dolls then bring them to a zone to solve a complex puzzle where you could alternate control of the dolls. Currently, you are only in control of 1 doll and this severely hampers the possibilities.

2. Hero/Ally Collection
Make it so that collecting different dolls enables you to open up new avenues of gameplay. E.g. If you convince the chef doll to join your cause, you can make 1st class food. Using that 1st class food, you can convince a hungry giant doll to join your cause. E.g. If you collect the construction worker doll, you can break down cracked walls so that Charlie can squeeze into them.

Refer to Suikoden for more ideas.

32907964.review:
Stacking is best summarized like one of its own Matryoshka dolls. 

[list]
  [*] Big doll, it's a fantastic idea that believes in its own vision. 
  [*] Middle doll, it's a bunch of one-note non-puzzles and walking. 
  [*] Which leads to the small doll, the core - it's boring. Unfairly so, to itself and to you.
[/list]

There's some stuff that carries Stacking. Visual gags all around, from the doll's special abilities to designs and presented situations. The weirdly but nicely intricate levels, for another - the Gilded Ship in particular could pass for a Quake map with its level of interconnectedness and verticality. 

Of course it ends with a one way street of a level, so not all good things last.

Carrying it the most, proudly flying at the front of the ship, is the entire premise. Playing as the smallest piece of a Matryoshka doll, you stack and manipulate bigger pieces, solving puzzles and disguising yourself from bumbling authorities - all within a Depression-era narrative presented as a 1920s silent film, complete with wooden acting.

Novelty is inherent to entertainment, and this novel premise is inherently entertaining. The amount of grand puzzles and adventures that could be made with it is astounding! It doesn't do any of that.

[h1]"Legend has it that the crown was split into pieces and can only be reforged by three mythical hobo blacksmiths!"[/h1]
[i]- if the writing seems like it's trying too hard to be quirky, yes.[/i]

In your typical walking simulator, they try to patch up the lack of gameplay with narrative and story. This is a collectathon with none of the platforming or combat, and patched up with finding the unique dolls, who shine and are impossible to miss, and performing "hi-jinks" for the sake of a completion rate. 

You can ignore the little collectathon aspects, but they're the only remotely fun part of the game. Otherwise all of your time is spent just ambling - slowly and awkwardly - to collect a doll, then walking back - slowly and awkwardly - to the quest area and use the doll's ability. If you are unsure of which doll to use, ask any doll in the immediate area. They'll just tell you.

This is 85% of the game. A litany of one-note stop and start prompts. Wasted potential doesn't even begin to cover it.

[h1]"I will not leave my post for any reason, barring sickness or mild unpleasantness!"[/h1]
[i]- this is about as hard as it's going to test you [/i]

This pervasive lack of momentum is broken on a couple of occasions - in the last level you're finally introduced to using multiple dolls to solve a puzzle, which leads to an inkling of thought. But it's too little, too late.

The Lost Hobo King is where Double Fine pulled out all the stops. There's puzzles, timing, lots of approaches involving dolls whose abilities make sense to use. Even the gags get attention, whereas otherwise the bad puns and toilet humour make it seem like a kid's game for a demographic that doesn't exist.

Combined with the level itself, if the entire game were on par with the Lost Hobo this would be a positive review.  It's where the game shines, and stacks itself to the potential it should have aimed for. It's also about 10% of the game.

[h1]"Time for a trim, boy!"[/h1]
[i]- a fairly inventive boss battle and final set of puzzles deflects my otherwise convincingly sour impression[/i]

Every game has wasted potential. That's just the fact of life, there's always ways that a game can be pushed, but isn't because they actually need to sell it and survive. But it's rare to find a game that so gleefully refuses to even touch the potential it has quite like Stacking has.

If you want to get frustrated with a game that doesn't really want to be one, or you're a doting parent who wants to get their child a game without any of the pesky dangerous thought or gameplay involved, this is for you. 

For everyone else, just move on. Much like the characters, this is a hollow, braindead toy where even stacking dolls isn't all that fun.

32692112.review:
[h1]All in All, it Stacks Up Well[/h1]

Stacking is a very charming little game created by Double Fine Studios. It was a side project, and it definitely shows in its limited scope and gameplay depth. Despite this, it's a game definitely worth your time if you're a fan of logical puzzles, and any puzzler should consider adding this to their library. Its style, design, and mostly clever puzzles make it a bit of a diamond in the rough, although I will admit that the occasional stinker, extremely short gameplay time, and the fact that its a little pricey hold it back.

The story is mostly a vehicle for puzzle solving and the stages' existence, but it deserves mention. In the early 1900s, Charlie Blackmore along with his family are a working class family of chimney sweeps. When they can't pay their bills, they are forced into servitude for the Baron, an evil industrialist that uses child slaves. Charile is too small to be of use, and is left behind. Using his ability to stack into larger dolls and control them, Charlie must save his family, end child slavery, and stop the nefarious Baron!

[h1]Hand-Crafted With Care[/h1]

The gameplay, although not very deep, is clever. Charlie, living ina world populated by Russian Matryoshka dolls, can literally stack into dolls larger than him. Each doll can be used for their special ability, which ranges from the incredibly general to specific to the point of being one-use. Dolls are of varying sizes (eventually leading up to a truly monstrous 6th size), and they must be stacked up one size larger than the doll currently being used. In the final stage, dolls' powers are combined, but that's basically it in terms of gameplay. Double Fine put care into how this plays, however, and this gameplay is still fun at the end of the game.

In terms of artistic design, the game is genius. It plays on the common trope of "Small characters use little objects for everyday objects" (e.g. matchsticks for fences). It uses this sparingly however, and the environment is majorily crafted to look like our real world. The mixture between these two themes plays together beautifully, however, and you feel like you're a small little doll, but the world is still pretty in its own right. It looks wonderful and everything works great together.

The most important part of the game, the puzzles, are mostly implemented well. It's all about using the dolls' specific abilities in conjunction with the environment to achieve certain goals. Maybe you'll have to dump out caviar, or save an ambassador from a race. Most of theses solutions are clever and make logical sense; you can make connections between presented concepts and use the context to help. They are fun to figure out, and the hint system helps if you really can't figure some of a puzzle's solutions.

[h1]It's a Small, Small World[/h1]

To clear this off before moving on, the music in this game just doesn't really work. It's a very short (~45 secs.) loop on each stage and it gets maddening quickly. Listen to something else while playing this game.

To continue from the last positive, I said that [i]most[/i] puzzles are good. Some answers are either ridiculously easy or stupifyingly obscure to the point of practically forcing you to use a hint. I can draw examples of both of these from the same puzzle: In the third level, an ambassador that is anti-child slavery has been trapped on the opposite side of a cloud of noxious gas. Two of the solutions to this:

[*]Use the hazmat suit directly across from the room with the gas.

[*]Use an opera singer's ability to sing near the gas. The logic you're supposed to find out here is that because she inhales heavily, she will inhale the entirety of the gas, freeing the ambassador.

[/list]

These are just two examples of how simply [i]bad[/i] some of the solutions can be. As a final note, the game also has a bit of a problem of putting the person required for a solution directly in front of the puzzle area.

Maybe the biggest problem with the game is the fact that it's short. [i]Really[/i] short. I you tried to speedrun this game, by finding one solution/puzzle, and getting no collectibles, you'd be done in about an hour and a half. That might actually be a bit generous. To this point, the first level of the game, of which there are only four, is the train station that acts as the hub world. The entirety of the first level is [b]one puzzle[/b]. One puzzle, and you're done with 1/4 of the game's levels. The levels get progressivly longer, and you do admittedly solve two more puzzles at the station later, but this only speaks to the lack of enduring content on display.

To continue, there is no replay value whatsoever. If you're a completionist, everything is perfectly available in one playthrough. I would suggest getting all the unique dolls and hi-jinx the first time you enter the level. Don't move on from a puzzle before getting all the solutions, either. I say this because if you come back, there is nothing new. You'll only be retreading ground with minimal enjoyment. The only exception to this in the game is a unique doll in the train station, which requires you come back after completing the Gilded Steamship, and thus making larger dolls available. Get everything in one playthrough, and don't come back unitl you want to start a new game.

Finally, the game can feel pricey. It's not a lot of content for CAD$10. The free The Hobo King DLC helps, but it can still feel a bit expensive. If this really isn't your thing, it's probably not worth the investment.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Overall, this game is creative, original, and fun. The team made a product with an excellent concept, and there was clearly a lot of love put into this. It is too bad that the game is hampered by frills around the edge that prevent it from ascending to the heights it deserves to reach.

[b]7/10[/b]

[b]Great Display[/b]

Stacking takes place in the early 1900s and follows a boy named Charlie. Charlie’s family is taken and enslaved by the Evil Baron and he goes on an adventure to save them. Stacking was a game made by Double Fine, the people who made the brilliant game, Psychonauts. I had a great experience playing Psychonauts so I got my hopes up when I saw the same people worked on this game.

This game like any game had some flaws. A big one was the camera. It was a touch to close to the character and was obnoxious throughout the game. The story was nothing special and the character development was almost non-existent. The interest of playing went down the farther and farther you got, and it began to feel tedious going through the levels. The music was repetitive and annoying except for the intro song which was fantastic. I ended this game listening to a podcast and wishing it had just played the intro song over and over. When the main way of telling a story feels intrusive in your game, something needs to change.

Other than that everything was unique and creative. The aesthetic while it didn’t really fit, was definitely something cool and new. The game was charming and the humor was ok. Nothing special and without the charm it wouldn’t have worked. Some of it actually fit into the puzzle solving aspect which is smart. The puzzles were mostly well done and hard to figure out and the hint system was done really well. 

All in all this game is pleasing to the eyes and not much else. If you like puzzle games, pick this up while it's on sale and if you have a kid you need to distract for a while, this will also work. $9.99 seems reasonable but it is overall a mediocre game. 5/10.

31208769.review:
Overall, a fun game. It combines the 1800s industrial feeling with steampunk and a zany world of stacking dolls. I enjoyed the puppet-like melodrama silent film style of the cutscenes.

One clever thing: your view changes depending on which doll you stack into. For example, I stacked into a seasick little kid. The display turned blurry at the corners and the camera wavered, just as you'd experience if you were actually ill. And the special action this kid has was to "Toss Cookies." 31062568.review:
Stacking was a brilliant game start to finish.  I played through the whole thing, including the DLC, and wasn't bored or getting fed up with it for a single minute.    

Having played the incredible Psychonauts, I have no idea why I left it so long to play "Stacking".  I think it was because it seemed 'silly', which is odd, considering I loved their other game about a bunch of paranormal cadets in a cartoon universe.     

As you can probably tell, the game is played in a universe where Russian matryoshka dolls live together.   The smallest dolls are "children", and the ever-larger dolls are grown-ups.   You play as a tiny child doll who has the rare ability to 'stack' inside other dolls.  You can only stack inside a doll one larger than yourself, but you can stack over and over until you're in the largest dolls.

The "levels" are set up with three things:   
* A story plot, which you need to play through in order to win
* A set of dolls which you can use to play the game.  Some are 'special'.
* A set of challenges and other fun distractions to do while playing.

The story is that your family has been abducted, and you have to go rescue them.   You start off in a "hub" level, the Royal Train Station, which in typical DoubleFine fashion is host to a number of fun and interesting puzzles.    From the train station, you take trains to the various 'levels' where you play through the story to rescue your family, and ultimately win the day.

There are dozens (hundreds?) of dolls in each intricately crafted area.  some of the dolls are 'unique', while some are clones.  If you stack into unique dolls, you get an achievement, and a little trophy back at base.    Each of the dolls has an ability, which can be used on other dolls.  Some abilities work on a class of doll (all men, or all children), while some abilities work on specific dolls.  The key to winning is working out which doll to use when.

The puzzles are all relatively easy, and you can play through by solving the puzzles in the most obvious way.  Usually, just talking to the doll you need to get past is enough to tell you how to do it.  For example one doll might say "I am scared of clowns", so there's your clue how to get past.     However, each challenge has between 3 and 6 ways to defeat it, and some of the ways are downright devious.   They're mostly pretty logical though, and I only had to google two of them because the combinatorial number of options was scarily large.  However in both occasions, I should have just been more patient.

The add-on DLC, "The Lost Hobo King" is a great piece of DLC.  It uses the same style and puzzle format as the main game, but adds a few new bits and bobs to keep it fresh.   The usual tongue-in-cheek slightly adult humour shows through in the  add-on.  

All the way through, the game tries to look "Victorian", with self-playing pianos, steam trains, zeppelins and monacled bad-guys.  The music is all twinkly piano music or violins, and the cut-scenes are shot in a style to evoke 1920s black and white movies.

This was a really fun, really nice little game. I really enjoyed playing it through.  Double-fine certainly know how to make a cute, fun game.

31062449.review:
I'm a fan of Double Fine and their creative style of game making. Unfortunately, Stacking isn't one of their finest games. It is, however, one of their most inventive. In this puzzler, you play as a Russian stacking doll who must save his family. Of course, you accomplish your goal by stacking into other stacking dolls, each with their own unique abilities. Each puzzle you're given has a few solutions, so the game encourages you to try out different ideas. It's most certainly very clever (and with a fun Lego style of humor to boot), but there's something missing here. The game feels too small and limited to really deliver on its premise effectively. Each puzzle only has a few set solutions, taking away the experimentation aspect of the game. It's also overloaded with cutscenes that take away from the flow of the game. Again, the premise is certainly there, but it seems better suited for a more open game more akin to Lego Worlds.

There's also such a weird disconnect between the gameplay and the game's style. It's a game about Russian nesting dolls that draws from old American silent films. There was a great opportunity here to play around with Russian culture, but instead we're treated to a somewhat arbitrary coal-era American setting. The stacking doll mechanic doesn't really connect to the game's themes or ideas in a terribly coherent manner, making the final product feel like a hodge-podge of mismatched ideas.

Despite it's flaws, this is still a very cute and clever idea from Double Fine, and as always, I tip my hat to their innovative thinking. But this isn't the best example of how great they are at making games. It's more so a fun example of how developers can think outside the box to make new experiences.

Stacking is a great little family-oriented title; fun for kids while maintaining a level of sophistication that adults can enjoy too as long as they aren't looking for anything deep. Part of the fun of this game is investigating all the doll types and their actions. Some abilities are useful, others purely for laughs. The nesting doll mechanic is not only artfully rendered but a unique spin on the idea of a character's inventory.  

This is a purely casual title -- nothing hardcore or super-challenging. While this lends itself to a bit of repetitiveness if you are hunting for achievements, the story (including it's DLC) can be completed quickly if you are looking for something that won't eat up a lot of time.

Unfortunately the game can bog down at points with overly long cut-scenes. But that's a minor point and easily dealt with my hitting the escape key to move on.

[b]Rating: 7.5/10
