30157485.review:
I really, REALLY wanted to like this game. I kinda do, but I am so annoyed by the amount of cutscenes that it colors what would have been a really fun, quirky game without them. Here's the breakdown:

The story:
You play as the smallest of a family of Russian nesting doll chimney sweeps, in search of his missing family members who were taken by an evil baron. You're tiny and scrappy, and it's endearing. It's a little heavy-handed at times, since the villain is a baron who's profiting from child labor. There are characters you can play as that are clearly all the big stereotypes from the Progressive Era, like oil barons, union leaders, a black lung kid etc.

The Mechanics: 
You solve puzzles by hopping into other nesting dolls, each of whom have a special power: digging things, hammering, drinking tea, flatulance, lighting things on fire, pouring soup, literally anything. The controls are tight, just WASD, Q for talk, E for your special ability, Left mouse to hop into someone else, right mouse to jump back out. There are multiple ways of solving each puzzle, and since areas are revisitable, you can do them all (and get achievements if you do!) but only one is necessary to progress the story. There are also collectible characters that you only get credit for if you actually hop into them, so people who like getting to 100% completion have a lot to do. There is a very fair progressive hint system as well, with three clues for each of the different variations of a puzzle, so if you just need a little clue or the full solution, you got it. That alone would have been perfect, but unfortunately the game ruined much of the mystery by telling you what to do at every stage, not just in the cut scenes, but also with screen popups and dialogue. So there's this whole mechanic of talking to different people, but frequently you don't have to, because the game already said, "Find this person, then go to this place and do this."

The music:
Fantastic. Lots of violin, kinda that small orchestra, lots of solo violin stuff and piano, very good turn of the century vibe.

The Art:
The art is, in fact, awesome. It's one of the reasons I bought the game despite negative reviews. All the characters really do look like Russian nesting dolls, you have large, revisitable areas with lots of detail. The aesthetics were good, with a silent movie era kind of vibe going during cutscenes, which brings us to....

The Pacing:
The pacing is fucking awful. There are SOOOOO many cutscenes to get the story across, unnecessarily long ones, too. For example, there are reactions cutscenes after EVERY SINGLE ONE of the times you injure the final boss. I'm not talking about a reaction animation, where the boss nesting doll gets blown apart, revealing another one of himself you now have to fight. That would be fine. But no, You have an unskippable cut scene where a group of the people come upon his discarded pieces, cheering each other on to "Get him!", then they pick up the pieces in a different way each time, then say something else, like "We got him!" then run off. AFTER EVERY ACTION AGAINST THE BOSS. Like, we got that he exploded. I mean, there are also huge, sweeping camera pans every time you entered a new area (sometimes 20-30 seconds long), as if to say "Oooo, isn't it pretty?" They gave a tiny bit of aid in showing you the general layout of where you're going, but since it was mostly in the 2D and you play in 3D, it's pretty useless. I mean, you don't get to play for the first 5 minutes or so of the game, and then when you finally get control, you go down one hallway, and there's another couple of minutes of cutscenes. It never ends. It's actually really sad because they were doing a silent movie thing with the cutscenes, and it looks great, but the devs clearly didn't understand that silent movies had hardly any dialogue in them FOR A REASON. It's like they wrote dialogue for the cutscenes and then said "Hey, what if it was like a silent movie?" and they did no changes to the script. Since the characters are wooden dolls, they can't move their lips, and have no visible emotions, so do we need to show them talking, then throw up an entirely too long paragraph, then have someone react to it while adding no new information (like to recap to another character the thing we just saw happen??)...WAY too long. If the dialogue had been spoken over the animation, the cutscenes would have been half as long and I'd have at least 30 minutes of my life back.

Overall:
By just inserting a skip function for the cutscenes, I would have given this game an 8 or 9 out of 10. But with the cutscenes...well, it burned me bad enough that I started the bonus mission and it started with another enormous cutscene and I just said "I'm out" and forcequit that thing hard. This game could have been wonderful, and if there was a way to skip the cutscenes it actually would be. I got it for $2 or something insane, and I DID like it during those few short bits between cutscenes, so I'd say I got my money's worth but I will not be replaying this.

5/10

30088858.review:
Stacking is a unique puzzle game using Russian stacking dolls, of all things. You must solve various puzzles using the dolls unique abilities. The trick is, you can only stack to dolls that are one size bigger than you. Even further, there are multiple ways to solve every puzzle.

The puzzles themselves are not hard to figure out one solution to progress in the game. However, to find all the solutions was difficult and sometimes not logical. Luckily, you have 3 clues for each solution you can reveal.  

The story unfolds using silent film cut-scenes. It adds a bit of extra charm. The environment and graphic design are well done. Dolls are uniquely stylized and the detail in the environment is more than expected for a game like this.  The whole game has a very Victorian, old style to it. 

Along with the main story, there are “hi-jinks” you can perform and also collect all the unique dolls. Both of these feats are not too difficult to accomplish. The hi-jinks only hint is in the title of what they are. It takes some thinking to understand what they want. I’ll admit I had to look at a guide multiple times. 

[b]Pros[/b]
+60FPS (not a true 60fps, camera still feels like 30fps. Hard to explain)
+Unique gameplay mechanic
+Great art style

[b]Cons[/b]
+Limited music tracks
+A few hard crashes to desktop late in the game
+Lengthy cut-scenes at times

Despite the last third of the game becoming repetitive and stale, I enjoyed playing Stacking. It can be a really short game if you choose to not find all the solutions and 100% the game. If you’re not a completionist, definitely grab this only on a sale.


[b]6/10[/b] Above average

29027033.review:
Best capitalism game ever. 10/10 would demand better wages again.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
You’re the smallest of a family of nesting dolls and you need to rescue them from an evil baron who uses the lower class as cheap labor. Political messages aside, the characters are simple and everyone has very little depth but it’s the humor in the interactions and the settings which show the creativity behind the game. You really feel like you’re on a boat or a train or a railway station while playing it. It’s not psychonauts levels of creative but it’s charming to say the least. The story can be ignored but it’s not a bad addition.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The concept is that you can nest into other dolls that are N+1 size from you to do specific tasks. You take control of them to solve basic logic puzzles. Imagine a 3D adventure puzzle game where you get other characters to do talks rather than doing it yourself. If you’re a adventure game fan, you’ll probably like the game because there are multiple ways to solve the issue using different dolls but the simple solutions are pretty easy. I think the concept is novel but only if you’re a fan of adventure games really. 

[h1]Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)[/h1]
The game has a home made aesthetic which is nice because it seems like entire world made of discarded human stuff. However, the performance is trash. It technically supports 144Hz but will barely hit 30 at times spending most of the time at 60. The game doesn’t look good enough for it so IDK. The cutscenes mirror a silent film with a piano in the background and the action done silently with cards that convey the story. I appreciate the artistic effort but it just takes forever to get 2 sentences of dialog out.

[h1]Final Thoughts:[/h1]
If you like adventure games, you’ll have fun with this. Otherwise, it kinda depends. Creative for sure though.

28809988.review:
Such a great idea! The matryoska-doll concept could create a perfect foundation for a nice adventure/puzzle game. Unfortunately, the game somehow fails to be entertaining.

The story is being told through silent-film-like cut scenes with the "title cards" instead of dialogue or subtitles - sounds funny but it results in extremely boring, endless sequences. On top of that these long scenes are usually basically just dolls jumping in front of the black background.

Music imitates the piano/violin high-pitched pieces being played along with these old silent films - again, sounds like a funny idea but it quickly becomes really irritating and almost unbearable after few hours of playing.

What's worst, the puzzles, the key part, are actually very boring to solve. Usually the solutions are so obvious that the main effort you have to put into is just running. Moving around could have been enriched by some jumping, shooting or some other interaction with the environment but no, you can just move forward.

There are usually multiple ways to achieve the main task and you are encouraged to find all the solutions just for "fun" but I must admit that after finding the first solution, looking for other without any purpose kind of lacks the “fun” factor. Also, it feels strange when the game world behaves like nothing happened. If you chose to skip these and just follow the story line, the game will end really soon.

I like the aesthetics and the original idea but the game was a disappointment.

27911102.review: It probably won't surprise many of my friends to learn that the family of one of my best childhood friends owned sets of nesting dolls and I was completely fascinated by those sets, or that I was a huge sucker (and still am) for the marvellous arrays and dioramas photographed for the I Spy! series of children's books.  These facts alone might tip you off that I might be biased just a little bit towards liking this game.  I do, unabashedly.  It's a fascinating, curious little puzzle game that hits basically all the bases for me.  The environments are full of small details and are quite varied, from fancy cruise liners to airships to trains and more.  The music is top notch.  There are multiple ways to approach the various puzzles and exploring these options is encouraged.  The aesthetics hearken back to a romanticised past that is, in many ways, charming and lively, though it does occasionally approach some of the darker aspects of life in the eras it pulls from.  Some might say it's somewhat short, which it is (I reached 100% completion for the base game and the extra campaign in about 8-9 hours), though this does mean that it is less likely to overstay its welcome.  I remember when my character first hobbled out of the train tunnel at the beginning of the game and saw the train station open up below me.  The view, with some sort of filter simulating tilt-shift photography (another thing I discovered at an early age and have loved ever since), blew me away and the game just kept right on going with those types of surprises.  It's not a big, AAA title, but it is an enjoyable little game and really stoked a sense of wonder for me.  When it comes down to it, I think that's one of the main things I could really want out of a game.

25200789.review:
Stacking is a game that despite its look that tends to draw more attention to younger people, has a really controversial topic that is child labor.
You're Charlie Blackmore a boy who leaves home to pursue his brothers who were taken and are now being forced to work, all his brothers were taken, but did not you too? Because for them you are too weak to work. When Charlie tells her mother that goes behind them, it is awful because he believes so small and fragile could not much. But she ends up letting him go.
As the name suggests we do is for the most part of the time to "join" the others, in a gameplay system developed based on "Russian dolls" or if you prefer matrioska. Your character to be very little you can get in other dolls and control them for as long as you want and the bigger the character that needs to be controlled, more dolls you need to have stacked. Each character has a unique ability (there are repeated characters) and they can serve as something to help the missions or may just be a joke. Speaking in Jest, there are several goals in the game and that is the main one being at every stage to release one of his brothers and others that are redo missions differently and mischief which is nothing more than awakening his evil side and out creating confusion, and giving slap or even wrapping someone made a mummy. These shenanigans you render something different in character (which made the conquest), usually it is becoming a part of the golden clothes.
The missions are completed in all possible ways, they release new characters to use and thus complete his collection phase. Although the theme is really heavy, the game pulls mood and you just end up forgetting the "dark side”.

Things that caught my attention in particular:
- The cutscenes are made like an old movie playing on an overhead projector, where it appears the scene with a piano music in the background and at times there is talk, text overlap the actors.
- Incredible soundtrack that will make many remember the old days.
- The scenarios are fairly large for this type of game and there are many things to do at each stage. As the details of each place is magnificent.
- But what caught my attention was the gameplay system that was what led me to make the analysis of this game.
Although Charlie is small, it is part of a grand game that is full of characters for every taste and can enthrall rats, cycling, shoot a cannon and even seduce someone. There are so many possibilities that the hours fly and you feel bad, because there is a multitude of situations to explore. Magnificent.

I loved the atmosphere of the game, the style of the era represented, the music choices, the silent film touches.  

The Hobo King DLC delves into a much quirkier sense of humour with a splash of epic saga thrown in, with a nod to dungeon crawling that was pretty awesome. I'd love to see more DLC outside of the original game setting - I loved the original but actually loved the DLC even more, it felt like more creative licence/control was enabled than in the original game. That part at times felt like one of the Lego games (smelly meat hats, man. Stanky good time!)

The bonus art shows a museum  - I wish we could have seen that in the game, and I wish Hobo Yaga hadn't been cut!

All in all, fun, casual, play/explore at your own pace. 100%ing it is satisfying, but not at all a bummer if you prefer not to.  The hint system is handy - if you use it, you're not penalized for it nor does it feel like "dumbing down".  I hope to see more DLC in the future, I'd like to come back to this game, but 100%ing doesn't leave much replay value for me.  Note: game is kind of short but it didn't feel overly short. It told its story neatly and kept things moving without feeling abbreviated, but if length of game play is a value factor for you, you might want to pick this one up on sale.

[h1]- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------[/h1]

Double Fine Productions has always made some great games set in a distinct universe with plenty of humorous things.
Stacking is a game set in a steam-(punk) world inhabited by living Russian stacking dolls. Unfortunately, this world is governed by the Baron a nefarious industrialist that mostly turns as many dolls as possible into slaves.

You play as Charlie the cadet of the family that need to rescue his elder brothers, sisters and parents from the evil Baron. Despite of his size he is very smart and perseverant and will be able to save his family through different area. (train station, ship, zeppelin…)

The bonus story let you play another story set in a medieval genre. In that story you need to save/help the Hobo king.
The main story features many cut scene as a silent movie with the slideshow for the subtitles! Don’t worry only the slideshow are in a black and white style.

The game concept is pretty simple but far more complex: as the smallest stacking doll you can stack into a larger doll up to the biggest doll. Each doll has their own ability. You need to use abilities in order to progress through your journey and complete challenges. There are more than 100 unique dolls so there is a lot of possibilities.

In each area you’ll find several challenges and each of them has different solutions. You’ll also find some unique dolls and have several small hidden challenges in each world called Hi-jinks. You can track your unique dolls, Hi-jinks and Challenges at any time through the menu. Also you can freely travel to the different area when you’ve unlocked them.

To unlock a unique doll you only need to stack into it, and perhaps use its ability. 

Hi-jinks are small secret in-game achievements: they are revealed once you made the right interaction using an ability. Like one Hi-jinks asks you to play tag with 5 different child dolls so when you’ve done your first tag the Hi-jink will be revealed and tracked.

Finally when you’ve perfected a whole world you unlock an awesome decoration in your hideout.

I would recommend this game to any puzzle-gamer that wants challenges.

22825731.review:
Messiah is a pretty interesting game overall. Taking control of a child who could possess any person as long as they are unaware, you could traverse intricately designed locations in order to learn an unusual story. A downfall of that game was only that it came before its time.

Stacking, however, isn't Messiah. Its characters are completely flat, the story left me failing to care, and, worst of all, even though you anticipate an intricate game of expertly using your matryoshkas like a point and click adventure inventory, Stacking is not an adventure, it is simply a collectathon. 

An example of what I am talking about: a room is filled with malodorous gas, which has to be bypassed. How to solve it? There is a hazard suit literally directly opposite to the room. Puzzle solved. Congratulations. This is a late-game puzzle. There are about four of these per chapter, for a total of four chapters.

Where is the content coming from, then? Alternative solutions to the puzzle that are just as simple: such as using the doll whose farts smell wonderfully to override the order. 

Collecting unique dolls, such as a doll whose farts smell wonderfully. You will generally find all of these over the course of just solving the story puzzles.

Hi-jinks, such as using the dolls' ability to fart on other dolls.

In case you didn't know, there's a lot of farting in this game.

The ability to use one doll's ability instantly after the other to provide a "combo" is acquired extremely late into the game, is not particularly substantial, and, yes, you guessed right, half of those involves farting.

Music is the same three piano tracks over and over, the overall attempt at storytelling kinda tries to be a silent movie and fails, and the only thing noteworthy about this game is the interesting matryoshka art.

Overall, I rate this game a f4rt/10 and cannot recommend it to anyone. 

4/10

I LOVE this game. I had more fun playing Stacking than any other game I've played this year. It's completely different than anything I'd ever played before. I played using my gamepad and the control mechanics were fantastic, super easy to understand and use. The in-game menus are well designed, the hint system was exceptional; there's even a button that will create a trail to lead you to the next objective, if needed. The challenges were fun and often very humourous. Each objective has several different ways it can be completed so it's up to you if you want to figure out each way, or just continue with the story. Each character has a unique ability, like a gruel chef who's ability is to add thickener to different substances, a raccoon who can see in the dark, the seductive widow who can distract guards and the gassy man who's farts can clear an area of people. The characters move quickly (slow moving protagonists are one of my strongest pet peeves) and this is helpful because the locations get fairly large and you do have to walk around a lot. Totally family friendly and yet that never interfered with my enjoyment playing as an adult.

It's just so good. So fun. This is exactly what games should be like.

If you're looking for a game with high quirk, lots of humor, and a simple mechanic, it doesn't come much better than Stacking.  Basically a puzzle game with matryoshka dolls, you use your ability as tiny Charlie to borrow the abilities of larger dolls around you; it's a simple but fun mechanic that gives the game its unique edge.  The art design and music are wonderful as well, with cross between Victoriana and an old-fashioned silent melodrama.  The puzzles aren't brainbusters, but they do work your problem solving skills and some have multiple and usually amusing solutions.

The two main criticisms are what appear to be standard ones for this game.  First, Charlie moves very slowly, and in areas where you backtrack, this can be a pain.  Second, this game has pretty much no replay value once you finish everything in it.  Unless you want to go back again and play it for the atmosphere and humor, there's not much more to it.  The DLC is also very short, but if you can pick it up on the cheap, it's worth a look.

It's a cute game, and I would recommend it, especially for kids and child-like adults, but be aware when it's done, it's pretty much done.

Stacking is fun.  Not the most fun I've ever had in a video game, but it's that casual "I need a good way to kill an hour or two" kind of fun.

You play a tiny guy in a world full of people who are nesting dolls.  Those are the wooden dolls that split in half and reveal a slightly smaller doll inside, which splits open to reveal yet another doll.  You are the smallest one, so you can jump inside the bigger dolls and control them.  Each one has different abilities.  There is one who plays music that attracts rats.  There is another who turns a target plaid.  There is one who will put a hat on another doll for you.  There are even special "limited collector edition" dolls you can find.  You have to use the dolls' various abilities to open new areas and progress through the game.  The whole point is to rescue your family from an evil industrialist who is stealing children for his slave labor workforce.  Along the way, there are additional challenges you can complete, mostly for bragging rights.

It's fun, but treat it as a casual adventure or you will be disappointed.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

Stacking is a short little adventure game developed by the wonderful people behind Brutal Legend and Grim Fandango: Remastered. Double Fine Producitons hits the nail again with their cleverly designed and well thought out game

Stacking is an adventure game where you play a family of Russian dolls who get kidnapped by the Baron and are forced to work long cruel hours, plus the children get sent to work even more. The subject of child labor is found in the game

You have the ability to stack yourself into more dolls with each doll having their own ability. The game's gameplay is simple, all you have to do is solve some puzzles with the help of a hint system, they can be completed instantly. However, the game does offer you the ability to experience different ways and means on how you can obtain the end goal

The game is extremely short, clocking in at only 3 hours with playing the main story once without doing the side quests or solving the puzzles differently and the free DLC story added in which is shorter than the main game. This game is meant for people unlike me who are known as completionists. Completionists will have a ball playing Stacking and finding all the different dolls and such but for us players who aren't completionists, the game is extremely short...

The game's cinematics present themselves in a way that you are on stage watching the performance but it is also being filmed on old cinematographic cameras which adds a lovely asthetic to the game

Stacking is a wonderful game to play in one whole sitting, however, if it was still selling at its full price I would not of recommended it because of its such short length...

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

20428172.review:
This unique puzzle game with an amusing story is an achievement hunter's dream that may also appeal to fans of the adventure genre.  Definitely recommended for puzzle or adventure gamers, and a possible sale buy for other people who are neutral to those genres.

[b]Pros[/b]:
Quirkiness: So many unique characters, many with their own special ability, some of which can be used to accomplish objectives/goals or hijinx.

Story/narrative: Main story and side stories are well crafted and engaging for me, building a weird world full of stacking dolls.

In game guides/tips/hints: This game can be an open ended challenge, or it can be really simple using the game's copious notes, hints, and in-game guide to find where objectives are.  I personally haven't had to use them yet, but I may do it if I wish to 100% the game.

Art & music: They're all perfect for the setting and premise of the game.

Achievements: Not merely Steam achievements, but in-game achievements are rampant with at least dozens per area/level.  Also, each one can be returned to at any time after the main goals for that area are completed.

[b]Cons[/b]:
Character simplicity: They cannot jump, run, or have items unless related to their special ability or a special event.  Given the amount of in-game help provided, the devs could've made such mechanics work without degrading gameplay, but it may have taken much longer for the game to be released.

Potential gameplay length: Being 3 hours into the game, I've completed more than a third of one of the available two adventures.  So best case scenario, I get over a dozen more hours out of it.  Also, I'm not sure that I'd have the desire to play a sequel or game like this again unless they address my issue with character simplicity.

20012243.review:
A pretty simple casual puzzle game. Story is decent and the game presents itself like a silent film, using title cards in cutscenes. There are four (plus one DLC) puzzle areas, each with simple challenges and puzzles scattered around. 

Every NPC model has their own ability (though most are fluff and only needed for achievements) and you have to find the character(s) that can do things to accomplish the tasks. The puzzles aren't too hard and they offer an in-game hint system to help you out when you're stuck. It's hard for me to describe but puzzles didn't really give as much of a 'eureka!' moment where things click together (like Portal or Antichamber) but felt more like solving Scribblenauts puzzles. The challenge isn't necessarily finding a solution that works but rather finding all the solutions that work. The majority of puzzles can be solved by bringing the right NPC to the right location and using their ability, there aren't many combination/multi-step puzzles.

The way I approached each area was to explore the area, get familiar with NPCs and their abilities/locations, then go back and solve the puzzles. The world is small and detailled enough that I didn't get too lost or bored wandering around. The biggest road block for me was needing to look upwards (for birds' nests, elevated platforms, etc.) but the hint system helped me know where to look when I didn't.

I would've liked a run key so that I could travel to places/puzzle areas faster.

Sometimes they move the necessary NPCs closer to the puzzle area (which is fine) but it was annoying when I went to their original place (where I thought they would be) and couldn't find them. This is partly why I wanted a faster travel option (I'd go all the way to the opposite end of a level to find a particular unique character only to have to travel all the way back).

It's worth a look if you like simple puzzles where you have basic tools and then you pick the right tool for the job.

Stacking is a puzzle game coming from Double Fine studios. 

You play as a russian doll called Charlie Blackmore who is on a mission to save his family from the evil Baron. To do so you can take control of other russian stacking dolls who all have their own unique abilities, like making shocking alarm noises or pumping out water. 

The atmosphere of the game is very late 19th/ early 20th century with a lot of coal/steam power, victorian era fashion and a lot of the story being focused on child labour.

The controls are nice and solid and it really doesn't take long to master, however you can find that unstacking yourself will get you stuck a few times if you're not careful about where you do it. This wouldn't be an issue if there was someway to rectify mistakes, but if you find yourself stuck you will have to quit to the main manu and reload your save from there. 

The game is only a few hours long if you play solely through the main story without going for 100% completion, but there are plenty of other things to aim for. You can try to collect all the unique dolls in the game, try and complete all of the doll stack series' as well as trying to find all solutions to each puzzle and completing optional challenges in each area. 

There is also an extra adventure but it's basically the length of a single level, not that that's a bad thing as it prevents it from outstaying it's welcome. 

Overall the game is well worth playing and considering that it's only going to kill a couple of hours if you blast straight through it won't require too much effort. 

8/10

But this game managed not just to move the icons, it also set the spacing between icons to like 5 pixels, packing all icons tightly together, requiring me to go on a Control Panel quest to find how to reset it back.

I am not going even close to the game ever again after this, sorry. Most likely a good game idea destroyed by crappy technical implementation.

18695568.review:
[h1]A Review About Stacking[/h1]
[h1]About[/h1]
Stacking is a game made by Double Fine Studio which produces classic which I will not name but you are probably familiar with. Anyways what is this game about? A lighthearted puzzle game set in a world where matryoshka dolls replaces humans and everything is shrunk down, scaled and done in a way that would make sense for a matryoshka doll. Since they also incorporated silent era film stuff what this means is that dialogue are not voiced but rather appear on screen to the tune of piano and violins and there is no such thing as facial expression since everybody have prepainted wooden faces and they all speak by flapping their midriffs. -sigh- Anyways,

It uses a third person perspective with a simple story and mechanic that I will describe later but do read the critique section to learn about some of its flaws.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Gameplay is really really simple to the point that even a child could finish the game provided they are age 8-12. Basically you press a button to possess a doll 1 size bigger than you so you can solve the objective at hand with the doll unique ability. Sometimes you need to possess a doll several time so you can grab the larger doll, also some dolls cannot be possess until you clear the challenge since they will either face you preventing you from possesing them since it only works when you are behind them or they are situated in out of reach places.

So with the power of the dolls you must then use it to clear the challenges aka mission objectives that ranges from reopening the train station to stopping the food services which is nothing complicated and they all have 3-5 ways to clear them and by finding all the solution you will earn a completion mark and a unique doll. Some of the solutions can be a bit obtuse but thankfully there is the hint system which after a short period of time will give you another one so you are never really stuck in a level.

So after you finish the level you can either do the side challenges like collecting all the dolls in a set, doing bonus challenges, collecting all the unique doll in a level or doing hi-jinks which are basically doing mean things using a doll's special ability a number of times.

All in all rather simple, good for some fun and one of solutions for any given challenges are often incredibly obvious. Once you are done with a level your hobo friend will draw a mural for you and display all the unique dolls you have possesed and all the challenges you have completed. 

[h1]Option Menu/Performance/Controls[/h1]
Very basic, you have options for controls, game effect, resolution, vsync, and a few other things but no sound, also what is the how to play section and credits doing here anyways. The option menu is rather empty for most parts.

I manage to get 60fps on the highest setting although it does stutters when loading a new section of the map.

Controls are pretty good but character tends to feel like they are sliding at times since they don't really have feets but after a few minutes I got used to it. I suggest  a keyboard since the game don't really support controller fully.

[h1]Graphics/Sound/Presentation[/h1]
Graphics looks fine, all dolls have these sheen to them which suggest they have been applied with a layer of lacquer and dolls with soots and crayon don't have these sheen as expected. Enviroment are good, nothing of note.

Double Fine were aiming for a classical sound style and they succeded in that. Piano, violin and period style musics are used aplenty and dolls often grunts and do weird noises as oppose to speaking.

Now presentation. Double Fine really nailed the presentation, dolls have floating accesories since they don't really have any hands to hold things and everything else have been adapted masterfully. An example would be the animal which still uses the doll style and trains being made with pins and cardboards. Good point for immersion is what I am trying and failing to say.

[h1]Conclusion+Critique[/h1]
It has a good premise, good gameplay and they really nailed the presentation so what went wrong in my opinion? Simple.

The game lacks depth. The whole game feels like one big challenge mode  with nothing else to break it with. While fps may have turret section or sniping mission that goes quiet and 3rd person games have stealth section but Stacking have only the power of using a doll's unique power and possesion to get through the whole thing.

So if you are not a fan of those I suggest you look elsewhere. But for what its for if you enjoy hearing about this premise I suppose you might enjoy it once this game goes on a sale. 

Its short too, clocking at 5 hours for both the story and DLC with the story mission finished but not all the side challenges so there is that to consider.

Scoring Methology:
-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

Verdict: B-Rank. [Good for what it does but otherwised a bit short.

Credit:Thanks to meatking and smmoke for your help!

No Drama Just Review = http://steamcommunity.com/groups/justreviews

18694774.review:
Truly original ideas seem few and far between these days, with most games feeling like iterations on tried and true genre staples or else reinventions of the classics, but this feels like something genuinely new and unique that somehow manages to nail everything it tries on its very first attempt. The hook of this cute little puzzler is that every character is a matryoshka, a Russian nesting doll that can by climbed, or "stacked", into and controlled to command their specific ability, but you can only climb into a doll that's one size larger than the one you currently inhabit. This is where Charlie Blackwell comes in.

Charlie is the runt of the litter, the youngest and smallest of the chimney-sweeping Blackwell family, who've been tricked by the villainous Baron into hard labour across his various business ventures. Being unwanted in the workforce because he's considered too puny to be anything useful, Charles sets out to rescue his family and bring down the Baron and his empire, along with the help of his hobo friend, Levi. What follows is an epic adventure across land, air and sea as wee little Charlie stacks his way into a wealth of loveable characters and straight into our hearts.

Each of the four main locations has multiple challenges that can be solved in multiple ways using the abilities of various dolls. Abilities can range from shaking your tush as a beautiful widow to seduce and distract male dolls, to playing a flute as a pied piper and parading rats through kitchens or exhibits... or even just puking up cookies as a seasick child. There's a huge array of abilities, some useful or necessary, some serving no purpose other than to amuse and have fun with, but all are entertaining and encourage experimentation. I honestly had just as much fun using vital dolls to complete challenges as I did needlessly slapping some poor random waiter across the face with a glove for two minutes just because I could.

The characters are all incredibly loveable throughout (with even the bad guys being endearingly bumbling in their attempts to thwart our hero), but that's only one part of the wonderful presentation that manages to be so effortlessly charming in every way. Cutscenes are presented to us as a cross between a stage play and a silent movie and accompanied by some perfectly fitting ye olde piano music, all tying together the overall Victorian look and feel of every part of the game. The dolls themselves all have so much charming personality that's somehow amazingly conveyed through mostly static, shiny, painted-on faces, and the world around them largely assembled from everyday objects that stay true to scale next to the tiny little toy dolls. It all combines to an experience that has so much more warmth and heart than just about any other game I can think of and only adds to its already enchanting uniqueness.

If I had to criticise anything about the game it would be that the solutions to a small few challenges can be a tad, umm... "too imaginative" at times and the sense behind the answers feel a little stretched. But, unless you're a completionist, you only need to find one of the many ways to solve each problem and move forward, plus there are optional hints for each puzzle anyway, ranging from slight nudges to outright step-by-step guides, so no player should become too unstuck at any point. The free expansion, The Lost Hobo King, is perhaps a little less successful in winning us over, with its slightly more random feeling elements, but that's only in comparison to the phenomenal main game, and is still a fun hour or two either way, adding to the 10 or so hours to be had with the rest of the adventure.

Most of my time with Stacking felt like getting a great, big hug from a warm, fuzzy blanket and had me fawning over it with wide, glassy, wondering eyes for with just about every part of it. I really hope there are more games in the series to come and can't wait to see what kind of new characters and abilities we'll get to play with like dazzled kids rolling around with a new puppy on Christmas morning. Until then, the best present you can give yourself is a roll around with a cute little doll called Stacking.

18390117.review:
I really liked this game, it's chock full of character, humour and charm.

[b]Good Points:[/b]
[list]
[*]The characters are really well animated, despite not having moving faces or even hands these characters can display a wide range of emotions very well.
[*]Great sound effects, the impact sounds are well mastered and have bite. Also while there is no voice acting in the game there are sounds from certain dolls that are particularly amusing.
[*]Great soundtrack, the music is really pleasant and really helps to set you in the world of the game. It's quite twee in places but it really suites the silent film aesthetic this game goes for, especially during the cutscenes.
[*]There are many characters and they all feel unique. In a game where nearly every character is also a collectible you get to really appreciate all the work that went into designing them all.
[*]Some great humour, there's plenty of slapstick and a fair bit of toilet humour as well but I like that kind of thing. Letting rip an enormous fart in a crowd and hearing everyone comically screaming in disgust and running away never gets old for me.
[*]There's loads to unlock in the game and loads of extra challenges to complete. While I'm sure it is possible to storm through this game in a few hours, if you just choose the straightforward solutions to puzzles so that you can complete the story, the real meat of this game comes in the extras. Going through the game and unlocking everything, doing every challenge and finding every unique character takes quite a bit longer.
[/list]

[b]Bad Points:[/b]
[list]
[*]Player movement feels quite stiff and lacks a proper feeling of momentum. Wierdly it takes a while to get up to speed but when you stop walking you just stop dead, changing direction is also very sluggish.
[*]Stacking into one particular doll in a crowd can be a pain because many of them may be highlighted but you don't know which one you'll end up stacking into.
[*]Sometimes the solutions to certain puzzles can be really obtuse and just downright unintuitive. There are also a couple of puzzles where 2 different solutions were pretty much the same in effect and some others which were very different but end up just counting as just one in the stats.
[*]The sound in the game can be glitchy, though this may just be me. There will be certain times where every sound effect except the music and background ambience will just stop or be replaced by crackling and pops in my headphones. This only happens quite rarely though.
[*]Getting around some of the later levels can feel like a chore. When you're trying to complete a level 100% you will quite often have to find a specific character to accomplish this, it can mean trekking halfway across the map to find them and then bring them to where you need them.
[/list]

While it may seem that there are more bad points than good points I can assure you that the good easily outweigh the bad, this game is totally worth your time and money.

18246945.review:
[h1]Short version: 88%[/h1]
Ever wondered how would a Charles Dickens-esque story look like if all the characters were matryoshka dolls? You can stop wondering then, because this family-friendly action adventure game will give you the answer. 

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
In Stacking, you play with dolls. Well, as dolls. Russian matryoshka dolls. And the funny thing is: this game is not just for little kids, adults will enjoy it just as much, if not even more.

Stacking is the name of the game and the main mechanic: your goal on each level is to solve a set of clever puzzles by jumping into other dolls, taking over their actions. All dolls have a unique ability that could be the key to one of the many solutions for each puzzle. If not, then it may be used to complete an optional challenge for added fun!

All of this puzzling is packaged into a story that reminded me of Charles Dickens: early industrialist world with steam engines everywhere, pompous factory owners who try to oppress the working class even more by introducing child (slave) labour, and a witty little protagonist, Charlie Blackmore, who starts on a quest to save his kidnapped family, following the advices of a friendly hobo he meets along the way.

The plot is divided into 4+1 stages (train station, ocean cruiser, zeppelin, luxury train, plus a DLC stage in a shanty town), all with increasing difficulty and maximum doll size. The first two stages start out especially memorable with their level and puzzle design, but the second half of the game is blander with darker levels and puzzles that share the same goal over and over: get rid of the next guard.
Luckily there is a DLC/expansion after it, the Hobo King quest, which brings back the creativity of the early levels, bumping this gem to “highly recommended” status for everyone who likes a good adventure.

18244382.review:
I love double fine games, and I love puzzle games, so I figured: this should be an obvious hit for me. Strangely enough, it isn't. 

The music and art style is very well chosen for the russian-doll motif. The puzzles have multiple solutions (so you don't need to backtrack extensively just for one missing piece) there's replayability, and goofing off, and yet...

I find that after about 30-45 minutes I get bored and fidgety. I get annoyed at the camera that feels too close or too far, or has been clipped by an asset. I get annoyed at the fuzzy difference of being behind a doll and being off to one side. The simplicity and by-the-numbers-ness of the plot and the "easiest" puzzle solution. The interruptions of the abrupt cutscenes. At the animations I can't exit if triggered accidently. The occasionally pause-and-skip (which honestly, doesn't matter in a game like this where it's not about reaction time). 

Then I take a day or two break, and when I return it's all sunshine and rainbows and the game is extremely cute and engaging. For 30-45 minutes. So...I guess I recommend it?

18096684.review:
Si decimos que Tim Schaffer está detrás de un juego lo primero que se nos viene a la cabeza es el término "originalidad", cosa presente en todos sus juegos. "Stacking" es una muestra más del extraordinario talento de su creador.

Muñecas rusas, esa es la premisa inicial del juego, manejamos a las populares "matrioska", y a partir de ahí surge un mundo real en el que todos los personajes son muñecas. La misión es el rescate de toda la familia del pequeño Timmy y derrotar al malvado barón, para ello el juego se ha dividido en capítulos y se le ha dado a las cinemáticas un magnífico estilo de cine mudo, con su correspondiente música según la escena, en este sentido no podría ser más acertado.

Recorremos los enormes escenarios con Charlie y decenas de personajes diferentes, cada uno con sus habilidades (algunos gritan, otros arreglan cosas, otros pasan desapercibidos), todos en forma de "matrioska" y de la combinación que hagamos de cada uno de ellos dependerá el éxito de las misiones, según el objetivo deberemos conseguir un personaje u otro. Es muy importante interactuar con todos los personajes de la misión, y hacer todas las acciones que se puedan para progresa. Todo de forma divertida, muy amena y en el que se requiere paciencia y cierta deducción para continuar adelante. Los entornos son muy variados, desde barcos con infinidad de personajes, hasta estaciones de trenes, muelles..., puede hacerse algo corto en general, pero se amplia con los objetivos secundarios y la existencia de logros, que se pueden conseguir con algo de esmero.

En el escondite se guardarán los personajes que hayamos encontrado a lo largo del juego. El juego está perfectamente traducido. Incluso los carteles y letreros de las misiones.

Juego divertidísimo, muy recomendable para cualquier edad, muy original y con el que pasarás tardes agradables frente a la pantalla, aunque se puede hacer algo corto, el sello de Tim Schaffer se nota bastante.

NOTA 8,5/10

16872914.review:
How I Played
Stacking is a clever, colorful, family oriented little game, that is easy to understand and quite simple to work through.  I mean, hell, it comes with it's own cheats.. err, hints, even.
In fact, it seems that if one were to do only the main objectives, one could easily complete this game in about 90 minutes. But then, one would be stupid, because Stacking is, actually, not a game, at all.. it's a toy.. to be played with.  More precisely, it's a toy box full of animated old wooden dolls.  Robust characters, diverse in size and personalities (though, not ethnicity, as everyone seems to be white.)
But, wait a minute.. they're not just dolls, but vehicles, too! They're easy to jump in and outa, and speed around in, and take screenshots from.  And, as if all that isn't fun enough, each doll type possesses a talent or skill (from gross bodily functions to amusing cartoon antics) to be mixed and matched, and otherwise, experimented with, and giggled at.
Frankly, the only reason I ever moved on to the next level was to get more dolls, and different places to ride em around in.
 
How You'll Probably Play
In Stacking, you'll play Charlie, the youngest member in a family of old-world themed nesting dolls. They're poor (of course), but happy (of course), until one day when Charlie's dad goes out for a pack of smokes, or something, and doesn't come back. Eventually, and mysteriously, all of Charlie's older siblings disappear, leaving young Charlie the task of rescuing them, all.
"Don't worry, I'll bring them home." He tells his mother, then bravely bobs off in search of family.. and adventure.

No Matter How You Play
I think there's 5 levels, each with a main challenge, as well as some optional side trips. In general, the challenges are simple, and puzzle-ish (unless you're crazy enough to set it on hard), which allows for a stress free, laid back gaming experience.
Well, that is, until Charlie's last challenge..
You'll probably need to sit up a bit, to get through that one.

Notes:
I got my copy as part of a bundle, so paid about 1/4th Steam's retail price of $9.99.
This copy of Stacking also included The Lost Hobo King DLC,  which I have not, yet, played.

15474667.review:
I haven't played a puzzle adventure game of this quality in years.

The first thing that grabbed me was the vintage art style and piano/orchestra music that played throughout the game, in addition to the silent movie style cutscenes.  Cutscenes weren't a bore to be skipped through or used for a trip to the kitchen, i found myself laughing at the antics of the dolls even when i wasn't controlling them (and making them do hilarious things).

The puzzles in this game have multiple solutions, and while one is all that is needed to advance the story, the other 2-6 alternatives all offer more of that great cutscene action as well as introducing new uses for some of the same characters who make repeat appearances throughout the game.  The Hi-Jinks bonus objectives encourage you to fully utilize all the extras in interesting and fun ways.

Being as i'm a lazy type and enjoy a video game from my bed as much as the next grown man with a full time job, I will add that this game is VERY gamepad friendly.  Not counting the optional menu navigation, it uses a total of four buttons plus sticks, making it super easy to play in the dark, from far away, and on a medium sized computer monitor.

The ONLY downside I can come up with for this game is that it is short.  I have completed the main storyline quests and Hobo Kingdom extra area in only 20 hours with 100% completion on both.  I suppose it isn't a bad thing for a game to keep it concise with quality over quantity, but if the developers are still monitoring this, I'd love to see some DLC expansions to further explore the world of Charlie and his amazing Stacking world.

15423801.review: This game is a pinnacle of high art in game design. The classiest game imaginable. This unique blend of Victorian entourage, Romantic orchestral music and literary masterpiece made me explore the vast worlds of Tchaïkovsky’s 5th Symphony and Paganini‘s 4th Concerto. The exquisite vocabulary submerges you into the atmosphere of the noble society of the XIXth century. The level design is incredibly clever, and the game mechanics are so rich that... well, the amount of subtle gags and visual puns is exorbitant. A must-play for all gentlemen, aristocrats, classical music lovers, historians and artists. High art in its purest form yet interactive and humorous. It became my favourite arcade because it really pushed the boundaries of my æsthetic perception like no other game. It is highly recommended for people who want to turn themselves into members of intelligentsia, expand their English to the level of Flowery Sesquipedalian Loquaciousness or just experience some heartwarming moments. Hats off to the developers, for this is eternal classics.

14999096.review:
So, I usually try to write reviews for games that I've played within the first week or so after I've finished it, or after I've played a significant amount of time for a game that has no flat ending. For this game, it's been just over a week (about 9 days) as I've been pretty busy lately, and I thought I'd sit down and write a review now.

But funnily enough, I don't even really remember that much about the game, and it's only been a week! I get really involved into most games that I play and just sink myself into them. I don't play games while randomly talking to other people or anything like that. What that tells me is that this game hasn't left a big impact on me at all, sadly.

Does that mean it is a bad game? No, not necessarily. I thought it was fun when I played it, as the style of puzzles is unique for the most part, as you swap around with different characters who hold different powers, and you have to build yourself up (or drop yourself down) to proper sizes to get around the puzzles.

I remember the locations, like the train or the cruise ship or the station. I remember the game was tongue-in-cheek with its style of cutscenes and self-directed humor. But in the long run, it didn't excite me that much playing it, and I remember very little about what the actual puzzles were.

The puzzles, for the most part, are really simple in most cases, and you can just use Hints if you get that stuck for some reason. I like that the game has multiple ways to solve most of the puzzles, but it is still not that difficult to find them all, and each solution is usually just as easy as the others. If you don't go out of your way to find all of the solutions or to do the special challenges in each level, then you could probably beat the game in about 90 minutes.

As I said, the game isn't that exciting to play. I laughed at some of the cutscenes or characters, but eventually the style of the game wore off on me. I completed all of the challenges in the game as well, and while some were funny things to discover, it became annoying when I realized that the majority of them just asked to you repeat the same generic action of one character 10+ times.

In the end, there is no desire to replay the game, and as I've forgotten most of the details in the levels and the puzzles (short of their general settings), the game won't last with me much in the long run. I will likely forget it in a few more weeks entirely.

Double Fine is still a good developer, but (please excuse me bringing it up) Psychonauts still remains its best game, and it has stuck with me the longest. I remember everything about it and likely always will. That isn't to say that others won't love this game more than I do, however.

So if the general idea and style seems interesting to you, likely wait for a sale if you want to try it out. It won't take that long to get through, and it is still decently fun in-the-moment. But looking back on it, its unique theme didn't actually make it that special.

It's a fun little puzzle game where the gimmick is that you play as those little Russian dolls that stack on each other (I believe they are called Matryoshka dolls).  The puzzles are quite creative and fun, and there are multiple solutions to each puzzle, allowing for a relatively high replay value. 14048236.review:
'Stacking', while being a game primarily aimed at children, manages to appeal to adults as well, not unlike other Double Fine titles.

Set in a fictional world of european industrialisation, tiny Charlie Blackmore, the youngest member of a family of proud chimney sweepers, finds his family abducted by the evil Baron and sets out to not only rescue them, but put an end to child labour as well.
In doing so, he has to make use of his stacking ability, jumping into bigger persons and animals, since all creatures in this world are Matryoshka dolls. With everyone being bigger than him, one could say that Charlie is the only one not being in some way hollow. Every doll has a special ability that may help Charlie on his way.
Overlooked or ridiculed by the bigger dolls, his only help is Levi, the hobo, who offers him a hideout and chronicles his adventures.

The concept is very well executed, making for lots of fun and at times quite tricky puzzles. There's multiple ways of solving the different situations, with a generous but optional hint system suited to all ages. On top of that there are lots of optional mini quests, involving all kinds of shenanigans, encouraging one to try out all possible combinations of stacking. There's much to explore and delight in in this small world.

Much effort is put into details. Difference in height when using different dolls changes perspective, field of vision, depth of focus and perception of sound. When jumping into a dog the colours fade, and so on.

The humour ranges from fart jokes to more mature themes such as the seductive black widow or that creepy guy who stares at women.

Along with the PC version comes the only DLC, in which Charlie returns the favour done to him by the hobos; finding the lost hobo king of Camelfoot is just as enjoyable as the main game.

This one comes highly recommended, whether you want to play it alone or together with your kids. Since some of it's themes are quite dark, it's probably not suited for toddlers as tiny as Charlie, unless you lend them a hand. Despite the grim tones, there's still a happy end.
If you like titles like Costume Quest, this one's right up your alley, but keep in mind that the alley is in some places quite a dark one, with monsters called men lurking in the shadows.

14040648.review:
I'm torn on Stacking. 
I love the concept. Anything with matryoshka dolls is excellent. I like the sense of humor it has and there is a lot to look at which is something I always appreciate. The puzzles have obvious and less obvious solutions and if you like finding all possible details in a game this game gives you a lot of options. 
HOWEVER, I thought the viewing mechanics were astoundingly stupid. The view you have is the view you keep until you change it; so if you turn around, now you're watching your character walk into the "camera" and you don't see where you're going. It does not shift on its own. I can see some rationale for some elements of the game needing this but it is very tiresome and it made the very last challenge so frustrating I just gave up completely. 
The last challenge was also very arbitrary to me, as at no other point in the game are you expected to do anything quickly. 
I would recommend the game for the fun of it, but I did get sick of it at the very end. Going between it and another game would probably be a better approach. 
Overall, fun game but definite design issues and has the downside of becoming monotonous.

13251012.review:
Love it. Definitely one of the most original games I've played in a very long while: it's charming, it's funny, it's cute, it manages to be both easy and challenging at the same time, and most importantly: it's fun to play through and actually makes you -want- to complete all the extras and side quests! As an extra bonus, it's one of the very few games that I not only found had pleasant music, but I also liked it enough that I didn't care to lower the volume to almost nothing to avoid hearing it.
On the downside, cutscenes are almost unskippable (you can actually double tap esc to skip them, but only at certain points, apparently), but I can live with that for the most.

Edited (a bit more thorough) review below:

Stacking is one of the most original games I’ve played to date, and one of my favorites. I just cannot tell you how much I love this game. 

In Stacking you take the role of Charlie, the youngest in a family of Chimney Sweepers. His relatives are all taken away to work for the Baron, an Industry leader. Your task? To find and rescue your family, and while you’re at it, free the children that are being used in child labour by the Baron.

The game is just super charming: the visuals are pretty stunning, the nesting dolls are adorable, and they all have their own powers and personalities. You, being the youngest of your family (and thus smallest) will need to solve puzzles (how to get into and out of places, unlock stuff, etc) by getting into different dolls and using their powers to achieve your goal. You have to respect the sizes, so sometimes to solve a puzzle you have to get inside various different sizes of dolls.

What’s best about it, besides the originality of it, is that:
All the puzzles are very logical, thus making them both challenging but at the same time not impossible.
All puzzles have more than one way to solve it. Meaning you can go back and find all the other ways in which you could have solved the problem. in fact, you will definitely want to do this.

I found the humor utilized through it to be quite adorable and funny too.

The cutscenes are all made like little theater plays, and the music is just beautiful and very in tune with the game’s setting and style. 

The only downside I could find to this game, though, is that the cutscenes are almost unskippable (you can actually double tap esc to skip them, but apparently that works only at certain points because most the time I just couldn't skip them).

I would definitely recommend this game to everyone, regardless of age and gender.

I don't know what inspires the creation of an adventure/puzzle game about Matryoshka (aka russian-nesting) dolls, but here it is!

Like most Double Fine games, this one just OOZES charm and humor;  In terms of gameplay, it's all about exploration and puzzle-solving, but where most games of that sort involve hoarding items and using them in the appropriate way at the appropriate time, Stacking has you posessing recurring NPC types to utilize their special abilities or satisfy a role for each puzzle.

Also curious is that EACH puzzle has multiple solutions to it;  Finding any one of them and hurrying through the game is a piece of cake, but for the real puzzle challenge you'll want to go back and find EVERY different possible solution. 12978363.review:
Stacking is a unique puzzle game from the creative collective that is Double Fine, and follows a tiny doll named Charlie, who sets out on a quest through a Steampunk land of stacking doll people, using their unique abilities to solve problems and save his siblings, who have been forced into child labour.

While the game doesn't offer much more than its $10 price-tag would suggest, this neat little casual puzzle-adventure has a lot more going for it than meets the eye. Using Charlie's skill of hopping inside other civilians – in the way which stacking dolls are known for –. the player must solve various puzzles to progress further and rescue his family. Each puzzles has multiple solutions, so there are multiple paths of thinking for each obstacle, and it allows for an extra challenge should a player wish to discover them all. This gameplay mode in itself makes up the majority of the story-driven aspects of the game, and is both fun and difficult in trying to find those last few solutions by thinking outside the box.

The game has other aspects to it, however, all as equally fun. Progress towards 100% completion requires more than just problem solving, as unique dolls and sets of dolls (such as a family of tourists or a magician's troupe) can be jumped into and collected, and 'Hi-jinks' can be completed, by completing unusual tasks such as shattering glass using an opera singer doll. This is fun, and entirely optional, so if one gets too frustrating, it can be skipped with little consequence towards completing the story mode of the game.

The game also has good – if cliched – writing, and an excellent visual style, especially in the quasi-2D designs of the doll characters and the environments.

However, this game is not without its faults, and there are several. If long unskippable cutscenes aren't your thing, you may want to give Stacking a pass; its cutscenes, presented in an old fashioned silent movie fashion, are numerous and can get frustrating. Despite this, the game's runtime is still rather short, and I myself reached the end of the story in only a few hours. The controls are also slightly fidgety – to take control of a doll, you have to stand in a specific spot behind it, and groups of dolls can make it difficult to select the correct one; there is also a "Highlight path" function for if you get lost, but it takes a long time to run, during which you can't move, so hitting it by mistake is equally frustrating. The camera angle is also somewhat annoying when stuck as a smaller doll such as Charlie or another child, where it swings awkwardly and focuses on the floor more often than not.

Despite these shortcomings, I do still highly recommend Stacking as a fun casual puzzler to whittle away a few hours, and is an excellent package for its price; however, if one is put off by the above-mentioned flaws, perhaps waiting for a sale would be advisable.

Un juego de puzzles bastante original y divertido. Fácil de pasar en una tarde de domingo sin agobios. Lo recomiendo si tiene una buena oferta o viene en un bundle. Por su precio original no lo compraría ni loco porque por 10 euros puedes encontrar juegos muchísimo mejores o mucho más largos (éste te lo ventilas en 4 horas sin estrés). 

El juego consiste en ir resolviendo desafíos con las habilidades de los personajes que encuentras en la fase. Para eso tiene una mecánica curiosa de muñecas rusas. Puedes ir metiéndote de forma sucesiva en muñecos más grandes y usar la habilidad del que esté 'en la superficie'. Con esta premisa está claro que el juego no puede ser complicado: simplemente consiste en buscar al personaje que tiene la habilidad que quieres y llevarlo a donde tiene que actuar. Si eres especialmente torpe o tienes una resaca tremenda cuando hablas con los personajes te dan pistas que... en fin, no hay que Sherlock Holmes precisamente.

Lo que sorprende del juego es, sin duda, su estética. Los personajes son matrioskas que se meten unos dentro de otros por orden de tamaño y se mueven por maquetas en 3D que conforman el escenario. Para rizar más el rizo le añaden el aspecto de una película muda, con carteles de texto y música de piano. Esto todo muy raro pero también original. Raro, raro, raro... es de esas cosas que cuando empiezas a jugar te hacen enarcar una ceja y decir con miedo 'uy, que gafapastada...'. 

Pero bueno: el resultado es ameno. No es un juegazo pero se deja querer si te quieres entretener sin desgastar demasiado las neuronas.

My opinion on this game is mixed. It has nice moments, but it lacks quite a few things to be a great game. its attempt on replicating an atmosphere of the early 20th century is rather superficial. Cut scene screen flickering and vignettes are supposed to imitate silent films (for some reason, with theatrical backgrounds). Dialogs expose mediocre writing skills. Although the game characters are all Russian matryoshka dolls, the rest of the game has nothing to do with Russia or Russian culture. The idea of stacking gameplay is fresh, interesting, and somewhat addictive. However, the quests you are given are often depressingly immoral. A player seem to always end up breaking something, ruining something, spoiling something to get things done. The humour in the game mainly manifests itself in characters doing funny things; unfortunately, these things include vomiting, burping and blowing wind, which game creators, obviously, find extremely amusing. I suppose a plastic Chippendale chair imitation with a whoopee cushion would be a suitable analogy to the game's attempt to be artistic.

To summarise, this game is a nice take on an original idea, but it could have been (so) much better if it were made with a bit more sophistication and taste.

11843070.review:
Double Fine generally produces some fine games and Stacking is certainly one of them. Stacking is a puzzle game which teeters on the casual line. It’s gameplay and core concepts are based on the Russian matryoska stacking dolls, hence the name: Stacking. You play the smallest doll of them all, named Charlie, as you set out on a quest to rescue your chimney-sweeping family from the evil industrialist Baron. If you haven’t already guessed, Stacking is set in a miniature Victorian world inhabited by matrioyska dolls. Even the cut scenes are presented like silent movies on a stage. It is not quite to the same scope as Brutal Legend as it is less than 10 hours long, and it’s not quite to the same calibre as Psychonauts, but Stacking upholds the fine name of Double Fine.

Stacking does have the charm factor turned all the way up with a saloon soundtrack, a miniature world and an unlikely hero. When all the dolls get excited, they jump up and down, like they’re being moved with an invisible hand. Stacking doesn’t take itself too seriously. It was produced as a small side project while Double Fine were working on Brutal Legend and feels like one too. While I was happy with the $10 purchase, I would not pay more than that as there’s just not enough substance overall.

For full review, visit:
http://icarusreviews.net/2014/08/22/stacking/

11813930.review:
Double Fine never ceases to amaze me with the sheer amount of charm and originality they can squeeze into a game, and Stacking is perhaps the best example of this yet. An adventure puzzle game starring Russian nesting dolls, it's designed around the principle of, ahem, stacking your character inside other dolls in order to gain control over them. Each doll has a unique ability based on the character they play (for example a bear can scream at the crowd, or a seasick child can literally toss his cookies), and it's in using these abilities that you are able to open up new paths and solve problems in any number of different ways.

And that's what I found so enjoyable about Stacking. It's not so much the actual task of solving a puzzle that's fun, but finding the myriad of alternative, often hilarious ways in which you can solve a dilemma that proves so satisfying. Sure I can simply take control of the chef and toss the caviar in the gutter to stop buffet, or I could use the Pide Pipper to draw a band of rats into the kitchen and have then overrun the place. Even when the solutions become too nonsensical to guess, a surprisingly handy hint system points you in the right direction without completely spelling out the answer.

And of course all of this is wrapped with as much charm and personality as you'd expect from a Double Fine game, with terrific characterizations for the dozens of unique dolls, a brilliant vintage art direction, and excellent cutscenes that pay homage to silent movies. It's absolutely brimming with character and manages to tie it all back in to its clever puzzle mechanics, making a cohesive whole that might possibly be my favorite of Double Fine's recent games. It's a hard call, but regardless of my personal ranking, Stacking is a joy to play and you'd be missing out if you let something so fun and uplifting pass you by.

11681356.review: A charmingly goofy puzzle game, Stacking has you stacking into fellow Matryoshka dolls in order to solve challenges. Each doll has their own performable action which adds a bit of personality to the solutions themselves. The level prologues are told with 1920s film cards and a theatre stage which lends originally to the exposition and sets the mood well for the antics ahead. Hobos are cast as helpers and industrialists as effigy which, along with the child labor issue that sat quietly at the center of the story, suggested a greater commentary that wasn't elaborated on past that basic point. The same can be said about the act of stacking itself. It's sort of implied that the protagonist's ability to stack into other dolls is fairly unique, but neither that nor the fact that these other dolls have lost control of themselves and done things, often against their own interests, is ever commented on. Seriousness certainly isn't the focus of the game, but it ends up feeling rather like the dolls that populate it, hollow and with a fixed expression. It proves to be an enjoyable, if short,  romp all the same. Just don't go in expecting a whole lot more.

11496833.review: When I first got the coupon for this game, I was a bit skeptical. It doesn't seem like much, but after purchasing this game on a whim(it was 75% off for me thanks to crafting my Killing Floor Badge), I realized just how much I had underestimated this novel of a game. The game mechanics are amazing, and it all feels very fluent and only takes a minute for anyone to catch on and have a blast! The story revolves around Charlie, who is basically a midget child that everyone makes fun of for being so small, and his family, whom, at the hands of an evil Baron, are sent off to slave away mining coal, forced to work on ships, and generally anything that is considered a violation of child labor laws. Charlie, being as he is so small, was left with his mother. He then hatches the brilliant plan to master the art of body-snatching, and sets off on a wild adventure to rescue his family from the Baron by occupying the bodies of keymasters, flatulent old men, an ill-bladdered german boy, and a slew of insanely wild characters, all of which will have you laughing emmensely and enjoying yourself way more than the price tag would infer. If you have ten dollars, and you're on the fence about this one, STOP READING AND BUY THIS GAME IMMEDIATELY!! The story is of moderate length, and a bit lackluster with the progression(you start a level, solve the challenges and progress by train to each other level), but the challenges are the true soul of the game, both simple and complex, all of which have hilarious outcomes(making sea-sick kids vomit on maps, luring rats into a kitchen using Peter Piper's flute, etc). The point I'm trying to make is, it's an awesome game if you're looking for something whimsically challenging, full of comical humor, with just a touch of serious slave trading.

11328576.review:
If you love adventure/exploration puzzle games, you will love this game! Beautiful graphics, easy game play, original concept (which is refreshing in todays world of re-makes), and totaly fun! The game is also clean, with only some slight potty humor (one of the dolls farts) so it's safe for kids (my 7 and 5 year-olds love this game)! I finished all the way through, and I think I'm addicted now! Well worth the price, in my opinion!

In the game, you play as a little Russian nesting doll. You have to stack into other nesting dolls of varying talents, to solve puzzles, in order to thwart the Baron, and save your family and all the kids in your world. The game has a steampunk-ish vibe to it, and an old silent film theme; which means theres no voice acting, only subtitles, so you'll need to be a decent reader (not a bad thing in my opinion!) in order to really understand what's going on or where to go. The puzzles themselves wher not hard, but creatively fun to figure out; and there's hints given, ranging from subtle to "dead give-a-way", for each one in case you get stuck! Soundtrack was lovely, and the visuals were beautiful! Overall a fantastic game, and a new family favorite for us!
