11204781.review:
I've been getting more and more into puzzle games that have unique mechanics like The Swapper, Antichamber, and Trine 2, and I must say that I am really impressed with the execution of this game.

If you like puzzle and/or adventure games, you will really enjoy this one.

The music and aesthetics are fantastic, and the theme is industrial-era silent pictures-style (the cutscenes are delivered like a silent movie, with text given in between the scenes to illustrate what people are saying). Many of the environmental pieces come from real life objects, for example you will see playing cards used as fences, and popsicle sticks and pins littering the area. 

The story is decent, you are the youngest child in a family tasked with rescuing the rest of your siblings after certain events provided in the beginning. The controls are very easy to become familiar with and the tutorial is both helpful and non-intrusive. Learning curve is minimal due to the helpful tutorials and simple control scheme.

As the youngest and smallest child in the family, you are able to "stack" with dolls exactly one size larger than yourself. Essentially, you are body snatching the person lol. For each person you take over, you will have a particular skill you can use. For example, one of the most helpful dolls is a lady doll that can use "eagle eye," which will reveal any unique dolls in the immediate area.

There are special sets of dolls that you can get achievements for if you successfully stack all of them together. For example, in the first level there is a family that has become separated - stacking the son, daughter, then the mother will complete the optional side quest. 

The puzzles are not too challenging, and there are 3 available hints that you can use if you are stuck. The hints have a cooldown timer that is not very long. The first puzzle you encounter involves you having to find a way into an exclusive restaurant in order to clear out the guests (so the 3 people you need to body snatch leave as well).

For each puzzle, there will be different ways to complete them, and these things will all be represented in your secret hideout.

In the hideout, you will get a new wall mural for each level you complete. For each unique doll you collect in the stage, there will be a life-size model in front of the mural (similar to Fallout's bobble head collectibles). For achievement/100% junkies, you will love this part. There is also a mini painting representing the puzzle challenge you had to complete, and completing the puzzle every way (3 ways in the very first challenge) will complete the picture. 

Great game if you want a new take on puzzle adventures, definitely recommend.

11198159.review:
A great and fun game, not too difficult and not too easy either. It has a very good story line. Besides the main story there are a number unique dolls to collect and Hi-Jinks to complete. There are also various ways to complete the missions the story gives you.

All in all a fun game and I would recommend it.

11180806.review:
I probably never would have gotten this game if it wasn't part of a bundle, as I'm not that much of a puzzle fan.
I gave it a spin anyway and here are my thoughts on it:

First thing I've noticed: this game looks absolutely beautiful.
The whole art direction is nothing short of stunning.

You are Charlie Blackmore, youngest of the Blackmore chimney sweeper family, out to rescue your siblings who have been taken by the evil Baron.
The twist? Every character in game is a matryoshka doll/Russian nesting doll and every character has a specific ability.
Yours? The ability to stack into another character and use their ability!
With that you venture through various levels, puzzling your way to the rescue of your brothers and sisters.

If you're looking for a lot of content, this game doesn't offer it. The main game is not very long and the additional episode is even shorter.
But better to have game that is short and fun from start to finish, than having a game that takes along time to finish and features lot of boring parts, right? Right!
You also have the ability to solve puzzles more than one way on the same playthrough. Solved a puzzle, but can think of more ways to finish it? Just try it, then.
As kind of a sidequest are the "hi-jinks", which are tasks you can perform with special dolls you can find in the world. It's mostly annoying other dolls, but there's nothing wrong with that.

The game looks great, is quite funny and is fun in general.
Like puzzlers? Definitely get it. Not too fond of puzzlers? It may still be worth a look ;)

11179430.review:
You play as a russian stacking doll. 

It's both visually amazing and sonically as well. It's set up like an old silent film where all the characters "mouth" lines and it cuts away to the old film style of what they said. Has some beautiful baroque music accompanying everything and its truly a work of art. 

Plus you solve puzzles by stacking yourself into other russian dolls that are bigger and force them to be your body slave.

11167840.review:
While I am generally positive over this puzzle game, I am not sure about the price.
Reason for that is that it takes just over 20 hours to finish both campaigns and get all achievements, without using hints.

Bought this with a 75% discount coupon, so I paid only 2.50, but even now I wonder if it was worth even that.
Please do not buy this game for anything more than 2.50, but should it ever be at 90% discount, this is a nice thing for you to have.

Pro :

The concept of this game (stacking dolls) is unique, and refreshing, I really liked it.
As a result the main storyline puzzles were a challenge, even to me as a mature experienced puzzler.
Still the puzzles are completely solvable without using hints or guides even a single time.

Most of the easter-eggs (called Hi-Jinks in this game) were also solvable without needed to use a guide

The looks of the game were quite nice, and just enough cutscenes excist to not be anoying yet still keep you entertained.

Game control is smooth, while clearly made to be operated on a console (hate consoles), it still performed well on pc with mouse and keyboard.

Game has cards with it, meaning you get some return on your investment.

Con :

Game causes occationally memory leaks, even on high end game pc's like mine. Happens mostly when you get in area's of the map with a lot of active grafic effects and a lot of moving elements and sounds effects in the near vicinity.
While most of the time the game runs smooth, I had such a lag period for a few seconds 3 times an hour, enough to be a nuisance.

Some of the Hi-Jinks are not solvable without a hint, while no ingame options excist for hints concerning them. Having to use a certain effect on a said number of dolls at the same time, or only on a specific type of toll, without any hints towards that number of type, makes them unsolvable without a walktrough or sheer luck.

11147716.review:
I've bought and played through this game twice now (the first time on XBLA), and it is definitely one of my favourite games.
'[i]Charming[/i]' isn't a strong enough word to discover how, well, how charming this world built of everyday objects is.

It's a great adventure game with lots to do in each of its 4 large locations (+1 equally impressive DLC location that is included for free in this Steam version).
The core concept of Stacking is that protagonist Charlie Blackmore can stack into characters exactly one size larger than him thanks to all living creatures in the game being Matryoshka dolls. Yes, those little wooden Russian dolls with smaller and smaller versions of themselves inside them.

Using this mechanic Charlie can embody almost all characters in the game and use their various abilities to save his family from the hands of an evil baron, or just have fun in the game world.
Everything in this game is thought through well, hints are available when you need them, both for story-critical and optional objectives, but only explicitly when you ask for them, it's super easy to see what things you're still missing before you've fully completed a location and you can revisit places you've already cleared the story for if you want to come back and do the optional stuff later.

This game is a delight and there's nobody that I would not recommend this to.

10948473.review:
Stacking is one of those rare games that is both charming, fun to play, and not from Nintendo.

You are Charlie Blackmore, a tiny stacking matryoshka doll, who is the youngest in a family of chimney sweepers/cleaners. Set in an era where child labor is still prominent and industrial corporations rule, a mean Baron orders children to hard labor, taking away Charlie's elder brothers and sisters, but not him, as he is too small for labor. Only left with his mother, Charlie sets out to save his father and siblings.

The game is told like a silent film with obvious stage backdrops during the cutscenes, but the in-game gameplay is magnificent, full of wonderful graphics, models and surprisingly well painted textures. Although Double Fine made this game during the Amnesia Fortnight period, where they were in limbo with the publishing of Brutal Legend, it's clear that they spent the time and craftmanship to make this game what it is, wonderful and joyous.

It's not a particularly hard game, there are a number of puzzle and a number of ways to solve each puzzle. But the easiest solutions are practically thrown right at you while you have to find, with some mild difficulty, the other solutions. The other solutions are unneeded though, unless you're a completionist, as the game isn't long either, about 4.5 hours to complete the game and the Hobo King expansion.

Very fun.

9.1/10

10907704.review:

It is failry short and can be completed in a matter of hours if you only solve 1 solution to each problem or at least 5-7 hours if you choose to do everything which is perfectly fine for what the game is. Basically its a fun little game with a fair amount of stuff to do if you choose to do them (Collecting all characters, completing all puzzles, complete optional challenges etc). 

At £6.99 / $9.99 its an absulute bargain!

Juego indie en el que mediante rompezabezas más o menos ligeros debes completar la historia en la que te involucra: un chico menospreciado de la plebe que intenta salvar al resto de su familia de la tiranía del Barón. Estoy contenta con los gráficos y con la originalidad en general de su desarrollo puesto que ya que lo juegas, debes descubrir todas las soluciones posibles y completar los retos secundarios para disfrutarlo un poco más si no tienes el DLC.

I loved playing Stacking, it was an adventure game that reminded me of older giants in the genre like the various games that LucasArts had made in the eighties due to how fun it was. What is more important is that the game gave me entirely new memories because of how original it was in its design and execution. The game didn't drag on either, it was action packed, straight forward and gave me a wonderful nine hours of gameplay to beat the core of the game and the additional downloadable content. This is a game you have to get if you if you want to have fun and its a great way to introduce people to videogames if you are hoping to find some titles to ease them in. Happy Stacking!

If you want to read a more detailed review you can check it out on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/06/stacking.html.

10352529.review:
Stacking offers a very unique gameplay exeprience that I have not come close to before or since. Players can 'Stack' into nearly ever charecter in the game and perform a series of actions unique to these charecters, these actions help you solve puzzles and progress through the story. Each of the key puzzles you need to solve to progress has several solutions, this dynamic encourages the player to just have fun, see what each charecter is capalbe of and eventually formulate a solution to the problem.

The story of the game centers around the rather dark topic of child labour, but the whole thing is smeared layers quirky humour and incredibly charming game world that makes the Stacking suitable for gamers of all ages.

Stacking doesn't quite stack up to being the game I expected it to be.

The story in this game seems to be a little bland, and isn't really helped by the cutscenes which are a bit slow and tedious.

As far as the puzzles go, most seem to be a bit boring to solve. There were a few entertainign solutions hidden in the game, but once you've found one solution trying to find all of the other solutions for a particular puzzle gets a bit boring.

I used a keyboard/mouse setup to play this, and it felt at times as if the way the game's characters moved werea bit sluggish when compared to what I expected to happen. Not laggy or anything, but it just felt a little slow.

In the levels themselves, the video and graphics quality are quite good, howver the extended cutscene graphics can be a bit of putting and after a while you may get bored of them.

9975806.review:
Double Fine is one of those companies that receives heaps of accolades from a stalwart handful of dedicated fans, but that those on the outside look at without the rose-tinted glasses the see the truth of the matter: Double Fine is, at best, an alright game creating company, definitely not great, probably not fine, and certainly not double fine. Stacking is the third game from this company I've played, and probably the worst of the lot. It has its charms, don't get me wrong, but they wore away quickly for me, until all that was left was a mediocre puzzle game bereft of any reason to be attached to it.

Strangely enough, the puzzle elements of this game remind me of the Hitman series, where there is a single or multiple goals in a fairlly small venue that need to be achieved through one of various means, with plently of disguises to be worn and crowds to be lost in. However, without the thrill of evading discovery or the danger of imminent death, Stacking fails to make the formula work. Without any danger and the barest of motivations, I was ready put the game away by the second area of the game, and becoming actually angry with it by the third. It is a puzzle game in the sense that it is puzzling how it is even considered a game. A definite pass.

9946142.review: Matryoshka dolls... check. In a great game? double check. Made by Tim shaefer? Hell yes... get it people, you owe it to yourself!!!

Así que la mayor parte, el problema está en encontrar a dicho muñeco en el nivel.

Al final los escenarios son demasiado grandes y los muñecos andan demasiado despacio, y hay demasiadas cinemáticas que tampoco importan mucho (ni son espectaculares, ni aportan gran cosa a la "historia" que es muy sencilla).

El juego es precioso y no está mal diseñado, pero la mayor parte del tiempo ves la solución del problema instantáneamente y tardas en ejecutarlo, dejándote con una mala sensación en el cuerpo.

9594503.review:
Beautifully crafted game and a mechanic that feels fully explored given the length. Cutscenes run a little long, but the silent film reel & accompanying classical piano music (Chopin, Vivaldi, Brahms, Mozart) helped keep the "before your time" nesting/matryoshka dollhouse theme.

The puzzles themselves are not too challenging, but having three solutions for each puzzle pushes along discovery. Three hints are also available for every solution and start out obscure, which was great to hold immersion.

Only criticism was the exclusion of a "sprint" key. The game itself didn't feel slow, so this is really minor. Solutions are often close to the problem, but I often found myself on the other end of the map. Still a wonderful world to explore and the free-for-PC DLC "The Lost Hobo King" felt like another full level. Thanks again, Double Fine!

9538564.review: An amazingly well thought out puzzle game from Double Fine.  You play as a child Russian Matryoshka doll that has the ability to jump into other dolls slightly larger in size and control them.  Each doll has a different ability which is then used to solve different puzzles in the level.  You can keep stacking into larger dolls as you move up in size.  This allows you to accumulate abilities and to move different dolls around the stage that they might not have been able to get to normally.  This game mechanic is just executed perfectly.  There are so many different ways to play and solve puzzles that its sort of like Scribblenauts.  The game contains around 5 levels which should leave you with many hours of playtime to solve everything.  It's a definite recommend from me.

9378615.review: Double Fine do another brilliant game. Original and with it's own unique style, Stacking is a puzzle style game that uses Russian dolls as it's conduit to adventure. You play as a smaller than average (actually the smallest Russian doll in the game) Charlie, who is hunting down his family members who have been kidnapped by a mysterious group under the control of a man called Baron. Utilising his unique size he is able to go inside (literally) other Russian dolls to controll them and use their unique abilities to progress through the game. Unlike a lot of puzzle games, you are heavily rewarded for finding all the alternative ways of completing a puzzle, giving Stacking more play time then you would from a standard puzzle style game. The thing that I like the most about this game is the combination of unique game play and visuals that really get you hooked and encourage you to try out all the possible scenarios to complete the same objective, rather than creating an air of monotony or repetition. I would reccomend this game to anyone who wants something that is short, sweet and a breath of fresh air.

9279437.review:
Stacking is the best game about mind control, child labor and Russian Nesting Dolls you will ever be able to find.

In it you play as Charlie, the youngest and littlest child of a family of chimney sweeps. Your family is kidnapped, so you head out to find them, possessing other dolls and using their abilities to solve puzzles and proceed. The storyline is a classic naturally, but it's the premise of the game that really stands out, and Stacking has a lot of fun with its premise. You have a lot of abilities to choose from, accessed by literally jumping into another character's hollow body, and the solutions to the puzzles are clever and entertaining. While the humor of the game sometimes swings towards the puerile, there's a little something for everyone.

There's limited voice-acting in the game- cutscenes are done in a 'silent movie' type style, complete with rolling projector film. The art is bright and distinct, and like the gameplay, toys with its character model's limitations. The characters move like you'd expect a Russian nesting doll to move, if that's something you've given much thought or worry towards.

This is a great game for achievement hunters as well- the achievements are tied into completing each level to 100%, and are sensible and fun to finish.

9254527.review:
Stacking is another rather unique game from Double Fine.  It is essentially a puzzle game starring nothing but Russian stacking dolls where you try to solve problems by stacking into certain dolls and using their wacky special abilities.  It sounds simple, but the levels are large and there's a lot of dolls to choose from, so it can be quite difficult to determine which dolls will work for a given situation.  There are always multiple solutions and only one is required to progress through the story, but the game has a way of making you want to find them all.  It would actually be quite frustrating if it weren't for the hint system, which provides 3 increasingly obvious hints (the last one actually tells you exactly how to solve it) for each puzzle solution.

The game is made in the style of a silent movie slathered with Double Fine's signature style, with all aspects of the game fitting together so well.  Doll abilities range from farting to charging, punching, and even firing a gun and other dolls will react in ridiculous ways.  They even look shocked when you stack into another doll, since you seem to be the only person with that ability.  It even fun just watching the dolls react to you when you're going about your business solving puzzles.

As an additional note, this game is locked to 30 fps.  It is the only game I've played that I feel has an actual reason to do so, given its silent movie style, but it still makes the game feel choppy and I would prefer being able to run it at a higher framerate.

So, Stacking is great fun.  If you like any of Double Fine's other games or just want a silly fun game to play, Stacking is a great choice.

9157252.review:
I'm amazed with this game... I really am. I had my eye on this game due to its peculiar art direction with the whole matryoshka theme. And, being from Double Fine, it should be good! Although I haven't really heard much about it, which now surprises me. 
I'm yet to play Psychonauts, but so far, this is their finnest! (...)

On to the game. Stacking is a third person Adventure/Puzzle game, in which you play Charlie, the smallest doll of all. The game is set in the industrial revolution era, a place where there's a tyrannical Baron who exploits workers and/or children. Your brothers and sister and taken by him during a workers' strike, and so you're on your newly found quest to rescue them, and find your father, who disappeared to pay off the family's debts.


Presentation
The art direction in this game is amazing! Everything shows character and is highly polished. In this regard, I can't find any flaws, really. The screenshots don't do it justice, but you get the feel of it. The cutscenes are done in an old movie style, without any speech and then added text, with fitting music. 
Despite the dolls' shape, their animation gives each of them a very unique feel, even in the way they walk and talk, which isn't something anyone could pull off.

The music fits every scene really well, with handpicked classical pieces, which contributes to the very unique atmosphere of this game. Even if you're not a fan of classical music, I'm sure you'll find it in its right place here. 
As for me, this might have given me the will to explore classical music a bit more. It's one of the game's spotlights for me.

Presentantion is simply excelent! I'm surprised with how they've managed to do it so perfectly, I really am. From the animation, to the cutscenes, the music... everything is just awesome and you'll find yourself just stop progressing and look around for the sake of it.



Gameplay

This is where this game is truly inovative, it blends mechanics with the world it's set it, gameplay and the artstyle just fit perfectly.
Due to your size, no one pays much attention to you. This is where the main mechanic comes in. You can Stack into other dolls that are one size bigger than you, and those can stack into others that are one size bigger than them, and so on.
There are Unique Dolls, with a name and a backstory, and a very personal feel to them. Then there are types of dolls, mainly a satirical depiction of their "class", I'd say. 
Every unique/type of doll has its own special ability that will help you solve puzzles or just interact with other dolls to simply have fun with the game!

In the main game you have 4 main areas (one of which is like the Hub area, which gets more quests as you progress) in which you rescue your family, solve puzzles and just joke around, each with a theme to it. Another area and sidestory is added in the DLC.

Each area the main quest, divided into smaller puzzles. To every puzzle you have from 3 to 6 different solutions, which are accomplished by stacking with the right dolls and using their abilities accordingly. You only need to solve them once to progress in the story, but replayability is highly encouraged in this game, for various reasons. Every solution is very creative and actually pretty fun, so I'd encourage you to try to get to every solution even after finishing the game, as you can go back to every area at will. The in-game hint system is actually very good, giving you little hints that will definitely help you solve some of the puzzles without spoiling it all for you!

Aside from the main quests, you have Hi-Jinks. These are essentially challenges to your creativity with the different dolls and interacting with each other to comical effect. Each area has a bunch of them, and I can't stress enough that you should definitely try them all, every side objective in this game rewards you.

In the main area of the game, you have the friend you meet at the start of the game, and he essentially keeps track of your progress, and creates dolls, wall paintings and puzzle pieces for each solution and unique doll found. In the end of the game, it's awesome to go meet him and see the whole cast of characters and locations in a sort of secret exposition.
This is a reason to do the sidequests and challenges, but do them for the sake of it, because every single one of them is very fun to do!

Story
The story is pretty straightforward, but it actually has many nuances to it and follows the world hand in hand, leading with some serious issues in a very casual and humorous way.  It's not something I'd examine very carefully, but I like that it's there, and it helps you understand the characters and the world better.


Conclusion

As if what I wrote was not enough, this was a truly brilliant game, in my opinion!
Everything fits, the world feels alive and is just eye-candy. While I'm not much of a puzzle game fan, this one pulled me in and made me keep playing until I've absolutely finished everything there was to finish in it! 
If you're intrigued by it in any way, go ahead and buy it. I'm sure you haven't experienced anything like it so far, and it's great to see some developers doing something they like and being inovative... and succeeding!

From the music to the artstyle and game mechanics, the writing... I can't find anything worth complaining about. The only problem one might have with it is the fact that it's a puzzle game, but the fact that it has several solutions makes at least one of them fairly easy to get, even if a couple of them were a bit hard to get if you hadn't talked to the right people.

Enough of this chatter. Buy this game if you haven't already, it's awesome!

9148809.review: Stacking is a fantastic and easy-going adventure game, built upon Double Fine's strong standard of entertaining writing and solid puzzles. While you won't be pixel-hunting for the perfect spot to push a clock, or trying to combine your string and cup into a flamethrower, you will occassionally find yourself perplexed by the hijinks bonus content. Overall, the charming and entertaining story, the beautiful aesthetic and setting, and the easy gameplay make this a good go-to game for any gamer.

9147372.review:
This is an entertaining puzzle adventure game. You play as Charlie, the tiniest wooden stacking doll. You can stack into other dolls, thus changing your size and what abilities you can use. In order to solve puzzles, you must find which doll to use in which circumstance.

You can also combo abilities. For instance, I lit a flame with one doll, but the fire needed to be bigger. Hmm, what fuel could I add to the fire? I found a stinky doll and used his "Flatulate" ability near the flame and it made a huge, satisfying inferno. Apparently I could alternatively have used a doll that spilled oil on the floor, but the farting was much more amusing. *giggle*

While you're playing the game, you naturally have to solve puzzles in order to progress. But for each of these puzzles, there is usually around three different solutions. You only need to find one solution in order to continue the story, but if you're a completionist, you can explore the area more thoroughly and find all of the solutions. You can do this as you go along, or you can return to the area later, even after you have completed the storyline.

While using different characters with different abilities to bypass obstacles is by no means a new concept, the implementation of it in Stacking makes it feel fresh and fun. The art style is adorable, and the cutscenes are designed to look like old silent films. I enjoyed this game quite a lot.

9110366.review:
[h1]AT A GLANCE[/h1]
(Full review follows below)

[list]
[*] [b]Game Name:[/b] Stacking
[*] [b]Original Release:[/b] 2012
[*] [b]Genre Tags:[/b] Innovative; Puzzle; Adventure; Avant-Garde; Lighthearted
[*] [b]My Overall Grade:[/b] A+
[*] [b]Estimated Playtime (Campaign):[/b] 5-15 hours
[*] [b]Multiplayer Aspect:[/b] None
[*] [b]Recommended To:[/b] Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Avant-Garde enthusiasts; Casual gamers
[/list]	

[h1]REVIEW[/h1]
This game is proof that innovation still exists in gaming if you look for it in the 'indie' realm.  [b]Stacking[/b] does an amazing job of offering fun, challenging puzzles without having any stupid, frustrating aspects.  If you're looking for a fun puzzler with a very fresh taste to it: pick this game up, you won't be sorry.

In [b]Stacking[/b] the basic mechanics of the game uses the concept of those Russian Matryoshka dolls that stack inside one another.  You play a tiny doll, and to solve puzzles you have to stack inside of various bigger dolls each with their own special ability.  You use this dynamic to solve puzzles as you progress through the game using different dolls and their different abilities to overcome obstacles.  It is an extremely innovative and refreshing concept, in my opinion, and I loved every second of it.  

The graphics won't leave you in awe, but they do the job.  The atmosphere won't send shivers down your spine, but it sets the tone. The story won't totally enthrall you, but it holds everything together. Regardless, the gameplay is so incredibly fun and fresh that the mediocrity of some of the other aspects are made inconsequential.

Play this game.

I got this game on the Humble Bundle and approached it hesitantly after feeling that it looked boring based on the videos I'd seen on YouTube. After the first cutscene passed, and I was set free into this world that feels massive and allows you to do so much all at once, I was hooked. I played through the entire game + DLC and got 100% completion with all achievements in what Steam claims is 9.4 hours. That said I did go make a meal and chat with my flatmates so it would be 9 hours all up. 

The game is just fantastically perfect and addicting. A game that actually makes you want to get 100% completion is rare for me so this game really is a gem in the rough. Though I doubt I'll ever play it again unless more DLC comes out, it was well worth the enjoyment it gave me. 

Bug wise I only had one moment at the end of the main story where the walls and floor became invisible and then closed my game, but nothing worth worrying about.

Overall it's a brilliant game and I'll be sure to keep an eye out for more titles by this developer.

8906929.review:
This game rides the edge of being a fun inventive puzzle game. They tried very hard to set it up. multiple puzzle solutions, new and interesting ways to work with puzzles by stacking into characters with special abilities, and a very charming art style. However they fail to execute. 

The game is enchanting for the first half of the game, until you realize that all the puzzles are generally the same, not always very intuitive, and often involve you needing to back track searching for the right doll to stack. After several puzzles it starts to feel that maybe they should have eliminated multiple solutions and spent more time on making more challanging puzzles. The dolls move around so where you left one you might need later isn't always where it'll be, nor will it be at it's orignal location. The story is overwhelmingly blaise though it's clear it was trying to be tongue in cheek silly, and the stages often have sections with very bad lighting. Even with the encouragment of  expanding your in game musuem of sorts,and little optional objectives it all feels very boring and pointless.

I would only reccomend this game if it was on sale, and if you're just looking to waste some time to get some easy acheivments, and enjoy some cute characters.

8903386.review:
Stacking - It's all about perspective

Double Fine did not disappoint - Stacking is truly one of a kind. A unique mechanic of possessing other characters by jumping into them is made possible through one fact - everyone is a Matryoshka doll! 
It maintains a very stylish approach to storytelling, constantly being very meta and aware of itself which is what allows it to be genuinely funny.

I really liked the original campaign ending (I have yet to play the DLC), especially the way they handled the 'boss fight' (including the slo-mo sequence - I lol'd) & the message it conveyed. 
In short: Witty, colorful and fun. Loved it!


V e r d i c t : AWESOMESAUCE, which means nearly perfect

8815311.review:
Un buen "minijuego" dentro de lo que busca ofrecer. El juego me parece genial en cuanto a diseño y sonido. Una mezcla entre cine mudo, guiñoles y muñecas rusas, con el toque de humor de Double Fine. Jugablemente peca de ser muy sencillo y tampoco inventa nada, pero su propuesta es ciertamente original dentro de su simpleza. El juego dura unas 4 horas si nos dedicamos a la mision principal, que pueden alargarse ligeramente si hacemos ciertos objetivos secundarios. Ademas, los "puzzles" pueden resolverse de diferentes maneras, cosa que nunca esta de mas. Dentro de esta duracion se incluiria una pequeña "expansion" que trae.


No lo recomiendo al que busque un juego de puzzles o una aventura, pues hay mil opciones mejores. 8770764.review: Stacking is another game that won me over with its gameplay, while also having enough visual charm to stand out from the crowd.  I'm a pretty big fan of Double Fine games such as Psychonauts and Costume Quest, but I wasn't sure what to expect out of Stacking.  Thankfully, the game keeps the quirky humor behind Schafer's other games while introducing a mechanic I've yet to see in any other game.  I suppose the mechanic of using NPC abilities for your own purpose has been used before, but not while combining it with Russian matryoshka dolls!  This gives a different layer of puzzles as you can only stack into dolls one size larger than you, and sometimes you need to be sure to stack into several particular dolls so you can use their abilities one after another.  Overall, Stacking is not too difficult unless you intentionally decide to seek out the extra challenges, and the narrative is pretty cheesy and unmemorable (which was a disappointment after Psychonauts).  The charm and the unique gameplay won me over though!

8265895.review:
Substantial enough to keep me entertained, clever enough to encourage me to find every solution to every puzzle and with the added DLC, a dynamic and intriguing world. The characters, the settings, the details great and small; like each Double Fine game I've played, I didn't want the leave the world behind when I wrapped up everything. Stacking is deceptively fun; it seems like it'd get monotonous and tedious, but there are so many small possibilities that even walking around and interacting with the characters doesn't have to be boring. The uniqueness of each doll is a stroke of genius; their abilities are unexpected and often quite funny, and as you start to recognize regulars from scene to scene you do start to feel a bit attached to them. Also, the protagonist is adorable. He's the tiniest kid in the world trying to save his family from peril, and he's so brave and optimistic that you want him to succeed. It's a feel-good story for every short kid like me.

One thing I will say, though, is that like many DF games the color scheme here is very brown and green, with rustic and dingy details. If these sorts of games make you dizzy or nauseated, steer clear, because this one's not very brightly colored and the camera is in constant, meandering motion to navigate around the surprisingly large environments. On my machine I wasn't able to use the camera without plugging in a controller, but once I did, Problem Solved and I had no other issues beyond that.

A short, sweet, clever feel good title. Sometimes creepy, often funny, and endearing. An absolute steal if you get it on sale.

8061932.review:
I don't like the goal I'm given in Stacking.

I have to practically create the institution of childhood - a very disgusting goal.

I stopped playing halfway through the game, at the Baron's zeppelin, where I was clearly shown that kids were supposed to be incompetent, unfit to do any serious job, that they were "naturally" interested in fairy tales and toys (as if adults cannot be interested in stories and games).

So, as a kid in Stacking, I had to contribute to the creation of the candy unicorn land, where children cannot own property, cannot work, cannot own themselves, thus falling into another slavery, and we're supposed to believe that it's slavery that we're saving them from.

Also, in a game featuring Matryoshka dolls, I would expect to see why communism is much more terrible than anything capitalism can do. It's ironic that in the train station near the ticket desks there's a poster, showing kids with shovels with a glorious shining sun behind them - this was supposed to represent children, enslaved by capitalism, but the fact is that it's communism that did that. In capitalism children no longer had to work because society got richer, and it's communism that produced such propaganda posters and enslaved both adults and kids with obligatory hard work.

I also didn't like how the whole game was scripted. Similar games, like the eco-fundie Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus and the nihilistic Messiah also feature possession of NPCs and puzzles based on this possession, but in these games the NPCs have reactions to your actions, they're suspicious to what you're doing etc. Not the case in Stacking.

I bought most of Double Fine's games twice, I supported their Kickstarter and I don't regret spending money on Stacking because of the general idea that the studio stands for. The fact is that I don't like the games themselves though.

The story is plain and takes a backseat to the puzzles themselves. The stages are very formulaic but still manage to keep things fresh by constantly introducing new dolls with new powers. Also, the asthetic design is strong, setting you in an industrial age silent movie for the cutscenes.

That said, I couldn't play the game for extended periods of time because I really just got bored with it. I did eventually finish the game but when I did I was glad to be free of it. If you love adventure games and the nesting doll posession tickles you then its a fine adventure game but for anybody else it is very difficult to recommend. I love Double Fine but safe to say Stacking is not among their best work.

Gameplay involves using abilities, Charlie's small size, or a mix of dolls to solve generally easy puzzles - you can beat the game fairly easily and quickly if you want to, but part of the fun is finding the solutions, as well as the hi-jinks (arbitrary acheivments basically) to get gold versions of some dolls. NPCs are honestly lovable morons, but it's their stupidity that allows the great gameplay to exist. Stacking is easy, yet challenging, and is another fine example of Double Fine's creative work. It's a shame nearly none of my friends have played this on Steam, but I assume some of them have played them elsewhere. Uses 360 Controller (or keyboard)

4334075.review:
Yet another great game by Double Fine, 
I thought the concept of this game was brilliant, the whole mechanic of the game and how you solve puzzles was amazing, it's so much fun to play this game. 
The storyline was great, the youngest member of a big family fights to save his family from being taken apart, even after being told he's too little to make an impact on anything. So it has nice little morals and such along the way, and even has a funny little extension to the story after the main game.
The main idea of the game being that you start off as a tiny little Russian doll, and as you know, a Russian doll usually has 4 or 5, maybe even more layers to it, and you're thrown into a busy world, with many different dolls walking about minding their own business. Many different characters with different abilities and you can jump into the next size doll up, to control them and make use of their ability. E.g. jump into the body of a guard to open that pesky door you needed to get through. It really opens up your imagination and there are many different solutions to each puzzle, so it really gets you thinking. If you choose, you can collect all the solutions and earn little trophies for your main hideout, which I loved, because I am one to love collectibles. But I’m sure you've picked that up by now if you've read any other game recommendations I’ve written.
As for art in this game, I personally loved it. It’s probably by far my favourite style that Double Fine have used, it’s a pleasure to look at, from a dark old sewer to a bright vibrant landscape, it’s done well in this game. 
This was definitely a fun game to 100%, its worth a go if you love unique puzzle games, with a fun and engaging element to it.

The game itself was very fun; the stacking mechanic truly unique and definitely not something I have ever seen before, nor something I feel could ever be replicated. 

Doublefine have once again created a fantastic little game, complete with their own stylised sense of humour. 

I would recommend the game heartily to all those who enjoy Doublefine, and wish to engage in a lovely little puzzle game.

As a con, I would mention, that, alongside Costume Quest, the game is notably absent from any voice acting work. Which, in Costume Quest, appears lazy, in Stacking comes across very well with the usage of old 1930s textframes (from silent movies).

Check it out!

3567114.review:
English (French below / Français ci-dessous):
original, beautiful, funny and full of surprises... a wonderful game!
In a Victorian-Steampunk atmosphere, the player is a small Russian doll, the youngest child of a very big family... Alas! all of them are kidnapped by a terrible baron, who uses kids as slaves in various places (a railway station, a Zeppelin, a cruise ship,...). The youngest kid must, thanks to his cunning skills and his brains, outsmart the baron and save his siblings and all the other kids... To achieve this, a single weapon: stacking! 
There are puzzles to solve and, to do so, the hero must stack into bigger dolls and, then, use their special abilities (sometimes weird or funny, like a glass-breaking singing, a rancid belch, a contagious sneeze or a very firm handshake...). Here, one of the great things in this game is that there isn't only one solution by problem / puzzle: with a touch of imagination, some logic and humor, one can always achieve something!! And if, like me, you are somewhat perfectionnist and you want to try all the possibilities, you can spend a lot of time torturing your brain!
After having been in the body of, among others, a mummy, an illusionist, a map maker, an opera singer, a fireman, a pirate, after having laughed a lot because of the surreal dialogs and the twisted scenarios imagined by the creators, you'll ask for more!


Français: 
original, beau, drôle et plein de surprises... Un jeu vraiment magnifique sous tous les angles!
Dans une ambiance et un décor victoriens-steampunk, on y incarne une petite poupée russe, le plus jeune membre d'une très grande famille... Hélas, tous sont faits prisonniers par un terrible baron exploiteur d'enfants et sont emmenés comme esclaves dans des endroits différents (une gare, un dirigeable, un paquebot,...). Le plus petit doit alors se montrer le plus malin et déjouer les plans du baron, sauver ses frères, ses soeurs et tous les autres enfants... Pour cela, une seule arme: un emboitement de poupées russes! 
Il y a des énigmes à résoudre et, pour cela, il suffit d'emboiter notre héros dans des poupées plus grandes, et ensuite d'utiliser leurs aptitudes particulières (très farfelues parfois, comme un chant qui brise les vitres, un rot épouvantable, un éternuement contagieux, une poignée de main très ferme,...) pour atteindre les objectifs. Ici la force du jeu est qu'il y a, à chaque fois, plusieurs possibilités pour résoudre une énigme... avec un peu d'imagination, de la logique et de l'humour, on arrive toujours à quelque chose!! De plus si, comme moi, on est un peu perfectionniste et qu'on veut essayer toutes les méthodes, la durée de vie du jeu s'allonge considérablement!! 
Après avoir incarné entre autres, une momie, un illusionniste, un cartographe, un chef de train, une cantatrice, un pélican, ou encore un pompier ou un pirate, après avoir beaucoup ri aux dialogues fantaisistes et aux scénarios tordus imaginés par les créateurs du jeu, on en redemande!!!

There is a bit of a learning curve when starting but it is not that complicated, carries a great art style and unique concept, and difficulty of puzzles can vary from easy to challenging. Most puzzles have more than one way to solve them. There is plenty of room for completionists in this game because there are collectables and other quirky sub-achievements. 4306187.review: Beautiful, utterly charming. Victorian flavoured gaming. Cannot recommend highly enough.

1422367.review:
Stacking is an interesting puzzle game where you have to stack yourself inside of other Matryoshka dolls and use their special abilities to solve the problems.

Let me give you an example, you need to clear out a party in a nearby room, so you find the doll that cuts nasty farts, and lay a stinker right into the vent that supplies that room with air; puzzle solved.

The game maintains that humor style throughout.  The visual style of the cut scenes is done in a style similiar to a silent movie and it works for this game.  The level design is very polished and everything meshes for this particular art style.

The only drawback of this game, is that each problem has multiple solutions.  It's good from the aspect that the game never forces you to solve a problem in any particular way; you're free to choose your solution.  However the game encourages you to solve the problem by exploring every solution.  This was fun for awhile, but the levels are massive and movement around them is not very fast.  So you figure out the second solution, and remember that the doll you need is all the way across the level.  Many puzzles have four or five soutions.  After you make this trek a few times it gets monotonous, even if the cut scenes are funny.  I got part way through this game and then let it sit for awhile exactly for this reason.  However I picked it back up and played it out to the end, just solving each puzzle once, and I'm glad I did as the ending was enjoyable with a quite a few hearty laughs on the way.

A good game for adults and kids alike, even though it delves into toilet humor territory, it still keeps it clean.

1758501.review:
What a fun little game! Charmed the hell out of me. It's casual, more like an action/puzzle game, but it sure is effective.

It's a steampunk-like world in which everyone is a Russian stacking doll. Charlie Blackmore is a tiny doll who has the ability to stack with other dolls and take control of them. Each doll has a unique ability, which he uses to solve puzzles and rescue his family from an evil baron who's enslaving children.

Puzzles are relatively simple, but still require you to pay attention to your environment. Stacking with random dolls and playing with their special abilities is fun and rewarding. In fact, it's required. You need to know who's around you and what they can do in order to solve the puzzles and move to the next level.

There are multiple solutions to every puzzle, doll sets to find, unique dolls to "collect", pranks you can play. There's a lot of extra things in the game to keep you busy, and they're not just pointless busywork. They're fun to complete!

The style is charming, tongue-in-cheek, and lighthearted. Won't be much of a game for the shooter crowd or adventure game fans looking for a serious challenge, but the game strikes a nice balance between casual challenge and G-rated fun.

I bought this one without even playing a demo. The style and concept won me over. I had to find out how a game of stacking dolls would play out, and it was a fun little game!

3800740.review:
Stacking is another unique Double Fine 3D adventure and puzzle game that revolves around, surprise, stacking - more precisely the stacking of russian Matryoshka dolls.

There are dozens of different dolls in different sizes, each with its own ability that you have to use in order to solve the numerous puzzles and challenges. In the later stages, abilities of different dolls even can be combined to progress further.

Visually, the game is set sometime in the industrial era of the 1920's or 1930's, which is a very nice and welcome change from all the generic modern-themed games these days. A lot of detail has been put into the 5 different chapters to make it even more authentic.

While the game's story isn't exactly award-winning, the presentation and the cutscenes in stage performance and silent film manner are really well done.

With the additional Lost Hobo King DLC, the game offers a solid 8-9 hours of challenging puzzles and solid fun, so make sure to give it a try!

1320357.review: Stacking is the most refreshing game I have played since Portal (1).  It is one of those games that proves you don’t have to be rated ‘T’ and up just to be good.  While the game will seem short if you just play through the story it is, but if you take the time to explore this game is more than worth it.  The visual style is cool, the audio is crisp, the music is fitting and the story elements are well crafted.  This is a easy game to pick up and challenging to master.  It was gifted to me, but having played it to 100% I would value it at $25.

Fantastic visuals, appropriately themed soundtrack and silliness abounds!

Hobos, child labor and The Great Depression presented through the versatile game mechanic of stacking babushkas/matryoshkas - superb concept!

It doesn't play all that great though. Despite strong adventure game roots it's more of a casual game where you stack and stack everything in sight until you do something right, and win little bonuses and rewards for it. The better puzzles and little storytelling delights get somewhat overshadowed by the dominating repetitivness. Still, as a whole, an unique game to relax to.

857317.review:
Double Fine at it's best..

This is simply one of the most original and fun games I've played in a very long time.

It's based around a very simple ability. You are a very small doll who can stack inside other dolls. You can only stack with dolls 1 size bigger then you, but each doll has a unique ability or skill of sorts.. Some more useful then others.

There's multiple ways you can complete a task, and you get extra's unlocked if you do them all.

You might be thinking.. Should i get it? Well, the short answer would be.. Yes.. The long answer would be, Hell yes..

I haven't finished it yet, but i can tell you it's already payed for the entertainment I've gotten from it so far.

748858.review: Double Fine seems to have an intrinsic knowledge of how to make a charming game and, as a result, "Stacking" is a joy to play. Every little detail of the miniaturized world has been lovingly crafted out of marbles, matchsticks, and bits of string, setting the stage for an old-timey story of heroism, child slavery, hobos, and matryoshka dolls. Alongside this are puzzle mechanics that echo vaguely of the adventure games of old, complete with a few puzzles that have you wracking your brain for the solutions. All of these elements are combined into a completely unique, positively delightful, and absolutely charming adventure, making "Stacking" a game that everyone should take time to enjoy.

5401804.review: A nice little gem of a game which is certainly worth checking out. Though it will not take you long to finish, (around 10 hours) it will offer you a unique experience. It's amazing how an idea of stacking russian dolls was made so natural and intuitive. You can enter dolls one size larger, and use their unique abilities to solve puzzles. Puzzles aren't mind bending, so this game won't satisfy more demanding players. They're are rather based on loose association (often unusual) of dolls skills. Every puzzle has many possible solutions. Finding first is a matter of minutes, finding all soltions often requires more lateral thinking. What I really loved about this game, apart from sense of humour and natural usage of concept, was art. Game is beautifully designed and has a great vibe to it. Many unique dolls, interesing locations and nice "silent movie" cutscenes telling you story. Definitely recommending this game, but mind the length and decide for youself is it worth the price.

2865243.review: If you're into adventure games, this one's a real gem. Great adventure/puzzler with an original game mechanic.

3792036.review:
"Stacking"
This is a really fun concept, you can stack with dolls 1 size bigger as your current size, each type of doll comes with its own unique abillities wich help you solve puzzles/challenges and stuff, the game looks really awesome and has a perfect atmosphere. 
You are Charlie Blackmore and your familly has been taken by an evil baron who uses them for child.slave labour and its up to Charlie (who is the smallest stacking doll in the world) to save them and end the baron's evil reign.
Youll be amazed by the funny and lovable characters you encounter on your adventures.

2942302.review: A wonderful little bundle of uniqueness, as expected from Double Fine. Lovely music and visuals, and some truly inventive puzzlemaking. A bit on the short side, but I suppose that's reflected in the price tag. The game is padded out a bit by the Lost Hobo King expansion, which is a great little addition, as good as if not better than the main game. The gameplay aside, it has a lot to say about neo-industrialist Britain, so it's really as much a social commentary as it is a comedy, and it is great as both.

811441.review:
What a great game this is ! I played this on the PS3 last year and was pleasantly surprised. The artstyle is completely amazing, and charming, and I loved every minute of it. 
For those who don't know what this game is about; Stacking is a puzzle adventure game where you have to (un)stack into other dolls to solve puzzles.

The story is very basic and cute and ideal for a game like this.
 
But the puzzles are the heart of this game, and I'm proud to say that they're all very fun to solve. Stacking gives you the option to unlock clues (which I didn't use, as the puzzles are all solveable for pretty much everyone) and multiple ways to solve each puzzle. It's brilliant and adds quite a lot of replay value. Plus, there are a lot of other things to do as well, like collecting all unique dolls in an area.

There are no voices in this game, just basic sounds. And because of the graphics it works incredibly well actually. It all fits.

Awesome game, people !

[Rating: 87/100]

Ah, a new adventure game from Double Fine. Thats neat. I like the idea behind this game and the fact several possible solutions are obtainable over just a single, often ridiculously esoteric one. The use of the Matryoska dolls as characters is a neat idea for puzzle solving, but save for Charlie's backstory, they don't have much to do with Russia beyond that. Hrm.
